The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In the Matter of James R. Jones, II,	Respondent.

ORDER

 The Office of Disciplinary Counsel asks this Court to place respondent on interim suspension pursuant to Rule 17(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.  The petition also seeks appointment of an attorney to protect the interests of respondent's clients pursuant to Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.  Respondent consents to being placed on interim suspension and to an attorney being appointed to protect the interests of his clients.
 IT IS ORDERED that respondent's license to practice law in this state is suspended until further order of this Court.
 IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Daniel B. Lott, Jr., Esquire, is hereby appointed to assume responsibility for respondent's client files, trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating account(s), and any other law office accounts respondent may maintain.  Mr. Lott shall take action as required by Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, to protect the interests of respondent's clients.  Mr. Lott may make disbursements from respondent's trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating account(s), and any other law office accounts respondent may maintain that are necessary to effectuate this appointment.
 This Order, when served on any bank or other financial institution maintaining trust, escrow and/or operating account(s) of respondent, shall serve as an injunction to prevent respondent from making withdrawals from the account(s) and shall further serve as notice to the bank or other financial institution that Daniel B. Lott, Jr., Esquire, has been duly appointed by this Court.
 Finally, this Order, when served on any office of the United States Postal Service, shall serve as notice that Daniel B. Lott, Jr., Esquire, has been duly appointed by this Court and has the authority to receive 
respondent's mail and the authority to direct that respondent's mail be delivered to Mr. 
Lott's office.
 Mr. Lott's appointment shall be for a period of no longer than nine months unless an extension of the period of appointment is requested.

  
     
    s/ Costa M. Pleicones				 J. 
    FOR THE COURT
  

 Columbia, South Carolina
November 27, 2007

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the 
				Matter of T. Andrew Johnson, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26398
Submitted November 6, 2007 - Filed December 10, 2007 

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Lesley M.
  Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary
  Counsel. 
				Daryl G.
  Hawkins, of Law Offices of Daryl G. Hawkins, LLC, of Columbia, for
  respondent.Â  
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule
  413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to a
  definite suspension not to exceed one (1) year, retroactive to October 4, 2006,
  the date of his interim suspension.[1]Â 
  We accept the agreement and definitely suspend respondent from the practice of
  law in this state for one (1) year, retroactive to October 4, 2006. The facts,
  as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.Â   
FACTS
In November
  1998, respondent was admitted to the practice of law.Â  At all times relevant to
  this agreement, he was a sole practicioner.Â  In January 2004, respondent began
  to practice real estate law, primarily handling residential refinancings, and
  he closed roughly four to nine refinancing closings per month.Â   
In August 2004,
  Johnny Hoy contacted respondent and asked him to conduct real estate closings
  for individuals purchasing mobile home/real estate packages.Â  As a real estate
  developer/investor Hoy would sell the mobile home property and arrange for financing
  for buyers with BB&T.Â  Neither Hoy nor respondent knew each other or had
  business dealings before this initial contact.
Respondent had not previously closed mobile
  home transactions and had only limited experience in purchase transactions.Â 
  Respondent informed Hoy, as well as the BB&T representative, Robert Green,
  the manager of a local branch, of his lack of experience in the area of mobile
  home purchase transactions.Â  Respondent requested written closing instructions
  from BB&T and was told by both Green and Hoy that BB&T did not provide
  written closing instructions to closing lawyers and that, instead, BB&T
  relied upon their bank representatives to orally convey any applicable
  instructions.Â  Respondent received direction regarding the lenderâ€™s closing
  procedures from Green.Â   
Respondent learned that a law firm in Columbia had previously represented Hoy in similar transactions.Â  Hoy advised respondent
  that the law firm could no longer process the closings because of a
  disagreement with the firmâ€™s title insurance company.Â   
Respondent contacted a lawyer at the law
  firm and asked questions about appropriate procedures in back to back closings,
  mobile home transactions, and this type of closing in general and why the law
  firm had ceased representing purchase(s)/mortgagee(s) in real estate closings
  arranged by Hoy.Â  Respondent represents the lawyer told him that Hoy was â€œa
  straight shooter,â€ or words of similar import and the law firm only ceased
  representing purchaser(s)/mortgagee(s) in transactions arranged by Hoy because
  the firmâ€™s title insurance company would not insure mobile home/real estate
  package transactions.Â  The lawyer stated he hoped to assist Hoy in the future.Â 
  The lawyer gave respondent no warning or information which would have raised
  concerns about Hoy, Green, or the procedures which had been presented.Â  Â Â Â 
 
In addition, respondent learned that
  another attorney had also closed loans for Hoy in an identical manner.Â 
  Respondent represents he attempted to contact this lawyer, but was unable to
  reach him.Â  Â Â Â Â Â   
During the first transaction involving
  Hoy and Green, respondent asked Hoy whether the buyerâ€™s closings funds would be
  paid by money order or cashierâ€™s check and Hoy informed respondent that he had
  already been paid.Â  Respondent advised Hoy that advance payment of a down payment
  would require respondent to obtain approval from the lender and that he would
  inquire whether and how the advance payment would be reflected on the HUD-1
  Settlement Statement.Â   
Respondent communicated with Green who
  advised that the fact that Hoy had already been paid a down payment was
  acceptable procedure approved by the bank and that it was, in fact, a common
  occurrence.Â  Green also advised respondent that, as a rule, the lender did not
  â€œsource and seasonâ€ either down payment funds or title, thereby diminishing the
  need for the closing attorney to verify funds or formalize disclosure.Â 
  Further, Green advised that this procedure had been followed for a significant
  time by its two former closing attorneys, as well as an attorney in Aiken.Â 
  Once again, respondent requested written closing instructions but was again
  told by Green that BB&T did not furnish written closing instructions.Â 
 
At the first of the BB&T/Hoy
  closings, respondent presented the HUD-1 Settlement Statement to the buyer and
  seller and invited their attention to, among other things, the purchase price,
  the loan amount, and the down payment and asked if each was true and correct.Â 
  Neither buyer nor seller indicated the amount was incorrect or that the down
  payment had not been paid.Â  Respondent did not, however, devote any additional
  time or resources to the investigation of the acts surrounding the down payment
  in this matter and, instead, closed the loan as it was presented. Â Â Â Â Â Â 
 
Thereafter, from August 12, 2004 through
  April 30, 2005, respondent served as closing attorney for purchaser(s)/mortgagee(s) in approximately 48 transactions arranged by Hoy,
  most, if not all, financed by BB&T with Green.Â  Twenty-three of the
  transactions were â€œflipsâ€ where the subject property was purchased by Hoy and
  then conveyed to the actual/eventual purchaser(s)/mortgagee(s) in a second
  transaction at a value in excess of the real or initial acquisition costs by Hoy.Â 
  The HUD-1 Settlement Statements did not reflect the fact that the funds from
  the second transaction were used to fund Hoyâ€™s acquisition of the property in
  the first transaction.[2]  
Respondent became concerned about the
  methods Hoy was using to consummate the transactions and discussed his concerns
  with Green.Â  Among other perceived irregularities, respondent was concerned
  with 1) the back to back closings, title issues, de-titling issues, and valuation
  of the transactions wherein Hoy was acquiring the property then immediately
  (sometimes in the same day) conveying the property to a buyer; 2) the claimed
  down payment which both Hoy and the party purchasing the property from Hoy
  assured respondent had been paid; and 3) the possibility that some purchasers/mortgagees
  who qualified for loans did not intend to reside on the property and may have
  purchased properties for relatives who did not qualify for loans but intended to
  reside on the property.Â   
Green advised respondent that the bank
  took no position on who resided on the purchaserâ€™s property.Â  Further, Green,
  once again, told respondent that the methodology being used by Hoy was
  acceptable to the bank in all respects and that no other notification or documentation
  was necessary.Â  Respondent faxed the Courtâ€™s opinion in Matter of Lathan,
  360 S.C. 326, 600 S.E.2d 902 (2004), to Green and Â Â Â insisted on complying with
  the requirement of placing the letters â€œPOCâ€ (payable outside of closing) on
  line 303 of all future HUD-1 Settlement Statements.Â  Green indicated that,
  while respondentâ€™s request to comply with Matter of Lathan was â€œvery
  conscientiousâ€ and â€œnot necessary,â€ it would be acceptable to the bank.Â 
  Thereafter, respondent closed an additional thirty-seven loans involving
  BB&T and Hoy.Â  Unlike the loans in Matter of Lathan, the
  Hoy/BB&T loans were not sold on the secondary market but were retained and
  serviced by BB&T.Â   
In a significant number of the
  transactions, the â€œcash from borrowerâ€ line on the HUD-1 Settlement Statements was
  marked â€œPOCâ€ when, in fact, the amounts were not actually paid outside of the
  closing to Hoy by the purchaser(s)/mortgagee(s).Â  Respondent acknowledges that,
  under the circumstances of the closings, he should have known that this
  information reported to him by the buyers and Hoy was incorrect and he admits
  he eventually suspected this to be the case notwithstanding representations by
  the borrowers and/or Hoy.Â   
In one matter, Hoy arranged two
  transactions where he was receiving title to a property in the first
  transaction and conveying the property in the second transaction.Â  Hoy advised
  respondent that he had the subject property under contract with an out of state
  bank that was selling the property out of foreclosure, that the bank had
  allowed Hoy to take possession of the residence, that his contract to purchase
  had been in effect for roughly three months so that he could bring the
  residence up to a saleable state, and that he had made substantial repairs to
  the propertyâ€™s subfloor and replaced all of its appliances.Â   
The two closings were both scheduled for
  December 12, 2004.Â  On that day, respondent learned the selling bank had
  actually allowed Hoy to permit the eventual buyer to move into the property and
  the buyer had already taken up residence.Â  The selling bank, however, waited
  until some time in January to mail the January 18th-dated deed to
  respondent.Â  Respondent contacted the selling bank and attempted to obtain a
  properly dated deed which reflected the actual closing date of December 12, but
  the bank refused to do so.Â   
Respondent brought this situation to the
  attention of the parties in the second transaction, the lending bank, the
  eventual buyer, and Hoy.Â  The bankâ€™s loan officer indicated he would need to
  consult with his supervisor and, subsequently, advised respondent that the
  bankâ€™s position was that the loan on the transaction from Hoy to the bankâ€™s
  customer should be reclosed at a date after January 18 to correct any existing
  deficiencies.Â  Respondent inquired of the officer of the Register of Deeds
  regarding the process to ensure title was properly conveyed and was advised to
  record a corrective deed.Â  The loan was then re-closed per the request of the
  bank and a corrective deed was recorded which reflected a deed transfer date
  subsequent to the transfer to Hoy on January 18th.Â   
Ultimately, respondent learned that Hoy,
  Green, and the appraisers used by Hoy were subject to a federal investigation
  in connection with the real estate closings handled by respondent.Â  Respondent
  made a self-report to ODC.Â  Subsequently, another attorney who had also filed a
  civil lawsuit against respondent, Hoy, and Green, filed a complaint against
  respondent with the Commission on Lawyer Conduct.Â   
Hoy and Green were indicted by federal
  authorities.Â  Both pled guilty to bank fraud.Â  An allegation in Hoyâ€™s
  indictment states Hoy was responsible for falsifying the loan applications of
  borrowers,[3] in addition to falsely reporting that he had received down payments. Federal
  authorities advised ODC that respondent cooperated fully in their
  investigation.Â   
ODC does not contend respondent was aware
  of Hoyâ€™s or Greenâ€™s criminal activities.Â  Instead, ODC contends that
  respondentâ€™s failure to insist on certified funds from Hoy in his initial
  purchase of the properties was an unknowing and unintentional aid to Hoy and
  Green.Â  Respondentâ€™s error was the result of failing to devote adequate time to
  the investigation of the facts surrounding the circumstances of the loans and,
  specifically, to the alleged down payments.Â Â  Â Â 
In mitigation, respondent attempted to
  contact two lawyers who had previously represented Hoy and did speak with one
  of the lawyers about representing Hoy.Â  Further, respondent had multiple
  conversations with the bankâ€™s loan officer, Green, about the propriety of Hoyâ€™s
  transactions.Â  However, respondent did not realize that Green was engaged in a
  conspiracy with Hoy.Â   
ODC believes respondent did not
  deliberately seek to assist Hoy or Green or their co-conspirators in criminal
  undertakings or have knowledge of their criminal intent.Â  Respondent represents
  he saw no appraisals and had no contact with appraisers; ODC does not dispute
  this representation.Â  Respondentâ€™s title search was conducted by an outside
  abstractor and the abstractorâ€™s fees were reasonable and customary in the area
  and properly reported on the HUD-1 Settlement Statements.Â  ODCâ€™s investigation
  reveals respondent did not receive any additional financial compensation or
  other benefit from the closings involving Hoy and Green.Â  All fees received by
  respondent are shown on the HUD-1 Settlement Statements and his law firmâ€™s
  trust account ledgers and the fees appear to be reasonable and customary for
  work of this type in the Columbia and Lexington areas of the state.  
Respondent has no previous disciplinary
  history.Â  He has been fully cooperative and forthright with ODC and the federal
  authorities in connection with their investigations.Â  ODC submits respondentâ€™s
  forthrightness was demonstrated in his ready and candid admissions about his
  suspicions and concerns.Â  Â 
LAW
Respondent
  admits that by his misconduct he has violated the following provisions of the
  Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide
  competent representation to client); Rule 1.2 (lawyer may limit objectives of
  representation with client consent after consultation); Rule 1.7(a) (lawyer
  shall not represent client if representation involves a concurrent conflict of
  interest); Rule 4.1(a) (in representing a client, lawyer shall not make false
  statement of material fact to a third person); Rule 4.1(b) (in representing a
  client, lawyer shall not fail to disclose a material fact when disclosure is
  necessary to avoid assisting criminal or fraudulent act by a client); Rule 
8.4(a) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of
    Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(d) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct
    involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e)
    (lawyer shall not engage in conduct that is prejudicial to administration of
    justice). Â In addition, respondent admits his misconduct
  constitutes grounds for discipline pursuant to Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413,
  SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to
  violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction
  regarding professional conduct of lawyers) and Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be ground
  for discipline for lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute the
  administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into
  disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law).Â  Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by
  Consent and definitely suspend respondent from the practice of law one (1)
  year, retroactive to October 4, 2006.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this
  opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing
  that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BEATTY,
  JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., not participating.Â Â Â Â   

[1] See In the Matter of Johnson, 370 S.C. 495, 636 S.E.2d 620 (2006).Â  
 
[2] Specifically, the HUD-1 Settlement Statement did
  not show a concurrent transaction in which Hoy purchased the same property.Â  In
  essence, there was a transaction between Hoy and the seller of foreclosed
  properties (usually the bank that had foreclosed on the property) and,
  concurrently, a transaction where Hoy was selling the same property to a third
  party buyer.Â  While Hoy paid for his purchase with a business check drawn on
  his corporate account, respondent should have known that the short amount of
  time between Hoyâ€™s purchase and his sale enabled Hoy to use the same incoming
  funds from the second transaction to fund his purchase of the property in the
  first transaction.Â  Respondent acknowledges that the HUD-1 Settlement Statement
  in the sales transaction by Hoy should have reflected that the funds from the
  sale were being applied to the initial acquisition by Hoy and the â€œdue sellerâ€
  line should have been reduced by a like amount.Â  Â Â 
[3] It is not claimed that respondent had any
  involvement in or suspicion of Hoyâ€™s false applications.Â

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court


	
		
			
				In the Matter of Leroy Jonathan DuBre,	Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26399
  Submitted October 30, 2007 - Filed December 10, 2007 

PUBLIC REPRIMAND
   

	
		
			
				Lesley M. Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Ericka M. Williams, Senior Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				Leroy Jonathan DuBre, of Greenville, pro se.
			
		
	


 PER CURIAM:  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to either an admonition or a public reprimand.  We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Matter I
 Brock & Scott, PLLC, is a law firm with its principal place of business in Winston Salem, North Carolina.  At one time, Brock & Scott had several other offices in North Carolina and in Greer, South Carolina.  Respondent was employed with Brock & Scott as managing attorney of the Greer office from May 2005 to February or March 2006. 
    
  In March 2006, Brock & Scott was retained to file a complaint on behalf of Client A who was seeking a deficiency judgment on the foreclosed property of Complainants.  In March 2006, respondent signed the Summons and Complaint and Plaintiff's Interrogatories and Request for Production of Documents in the collection action.  The Summons and Complaint were served on the Complainants on or about March 31, 2006.  On or about April 18, 2006, the Complainants served their answer at the Greer office of Brock & Scott.
 
 On or about June 15, 2006, Brock & Scott moved for a default judgment on behalf of Client A.  The motion was granted.  Upon notification of the default judgment, Complainants notified Brock & Scott of their prior answer to the complaint.  Brock & Scott then notified the court of the error in seeking the default judgment and requested that the default judgment be set aside.  The judgment was set aside by order dated August 17, 2006. 
 
 Respondent maintains he took no actions on Complainants' case other than signing the Summons and Complaint and the 
Plaintiff's Interrogatories and Request for Production of Documents.  Respondent states that the Summons and Complaint and the 
Plaintiff's Interrogatories and Request for Production of Documents were prepared in the Winston Salem office and forwarded to the Greer office for his signature.  Respondent also states he forwarded the signed Summons and Complaint and the 
Plaintiff's Interrogatories and Request for Production of Documents to the Winston Salem office and all other matters were handled through the Winston Salem office.
 
 Respondent represents there were no attorneys in the Winston Salem office who were licensed to practice law in South Carolina.  Respondent admits that his actions assisted in the unauthorized practice of law. 
 
Matter II
 Respondent represents he signed an estimated fifty (50) to one hundred and fifty (150) Summons and Complaints for Brock & Scott but performed no other action on the cases.  He represents that in collection proceedings it was the practice of Brock & Scott to handle the entire action from the Winston Salem office and 
respondent's only function was the signing of documents to be filed with the court.
 
Further, respondent admits that his responsibilities as 
managing attorney for the Greer office included the marketing and closing of 
loans. Respondent states that when he solicited clients, he distributed a 
package of information which contained contact information for Brock & Scott. 
Respondent admits the telephone number in the material appeared to be a South 
Carolina number but was actually a "backdoor" number which directly contacted the Winston Salem office.  Respondent states the same was true for the facsimile number provided to potential clients.
 
Respondent maintains he became very concerned about the procedures employed by Brock & Scott in its collection matters and that he made several attempts to become more involved in the collections procedures.  He asserts he resigned from the law office of Brock & Scott when his attempts to become more active were unsuccessful. 
    
  ODC agrees respondent has been very cooperative and forthright in ODC's investigation of these matters. 
  
  LAW
 Respondent admits that by his misconduct he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:  Rule 5.5 (lawyer shall not assist non-lawyer in the unauthorized practice of law) and Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct).  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).
 
CONCLUSION
 We find that respondent's misconduct warrants a public reprimand.  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
 PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

				Elizabeth Van Doren Gray, of Sowell Gray Stepp & Laffitte, LLC,
  of Columbia, for respondent. 
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel
  (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent
  pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits
  misconduct and agrees to either an admonition or a public reprimand.Â  We accept
  the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the
  agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Respondent, a sole practicioner, employed
  Jean Knowles as a non-lawyer legal assistant from October 2002 through January
  2006.Â  Knowles assisted respondent with the preparation and closing of real
  estate transactions.Â   
In 2003-2004, respondent began
  suffering from a serious heart ailment and was hospitalized in intensive care
  and diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.Â  After release from his initial
  hospitalization, respondent had additional episodes and emergency hospital
  treatment.Â  He was advised by his treating physician to alter his lifestyle and
  to reduce stress.Â   
In January 2004, Knowles offered to
  reconcile respondentâ€™s trust account and to generally manage his trust
  account.Â  Respondent accepted the offer in an effort to reduce his stress as
  recommended by his physician.Â  During the time Knowles was assisting respondent
  with his trust account reconciliations, respondent reviewed her reports and the
  bank accounts but not the cancelled checks.Â  At the time, electronic copies of
  the checks were provided by the bank in CD format.Â   
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In December 2005, respondentâ€™s family
  began experiencing a series of deaths of close family members.Â  Respondentâ€™s
  sister-in-law died in December 2005, his father-in-law died in February 2006,
  and his wifeâ€™s uncle died in March 2006.Â  Knowlesâ€™ employment was terminated in
  January 20, 2006 for reasons unrelated to her embezzlement, which had not yet
  been discovered.Â Â   
In March 2006, respondent received a
  â€œNSFâ€ (non-sufficient funds) notice from the bank concerning his trust
  account.Â  Respondent represents to ODC that, after receiving the notice, he
  â€œmeant to report and investigate [that matter] but failed to do so due to
  several family crises in that time frame.â€Â  When preparing to respond to
  inquiries from ODC concerning the matters set forth in the agreement,
  respondent found the NSF notice and recalled receiving it.Â  Respondent agrees
  this notice was a red flag that should have caused him to make inquiries into
  the integrity of his trust account.Â   
In the Spring of 2006, respondent hired
  an independent bookkeeper to examine his trust account.Â  During the audit, the
  bookkeeper discovered that CDs containing copies of respondentâ€™s returned trust
  account checks were missing and requested them from the bank.Â   
On June 13, 2006, respondent was notified
  by his title insurance company that a check in the amount of $113,000 drawn on
  his trust account had been dishonored upon presentment due to insufficient
  funds being available in respondentâ€™s trust account.[1]Â 
  At the close of business on June 15, 2006, after obtaining access to the CDs
  provided by the bank, the bookkeeper confirmed to respondent that there were
  substantial shortages in his trust account.Â  On June 16, 2006, respondent
  contacted ODC by telephone, advised ODC of the shortages, and prepared a
  written self-report.[2]Â 
  An officer with respondentâ€™s title insurance carrier made a complaint to ODC
  concerning this matter.Â   
Thereafter, respondent deposited $30,000
  of personal funds into his trust account and made arrangements to close the
  trust account which contained the shortages.Â  Later, respondent deposited an
  additional $13,000 into the account to cover the shortages.Â   
Respondentâ€™s audit revealed that,
  beginning in January 2004 and continuing until her arrest in June 2006 (well
  after her termination in January 2006), Knowles embezzled $238,672.06. Â During
  that period, Knowles (who did not have signatory authority on respondentâ€™s
  trust account) forged respondentâ€™s name to 88 checks drawn on respondentâ€™s
  trust account, six of which were written after her termination by respondent. Â Seventeen
  of the forged checks exceed $5,100.Â  All of the forged checks were made payable
  to Knowles, her husband, or her children.  
Not until after making the self-report to ODC did respondent request his bank notify ODC of any overdrafts on his trust
  account as required by Rule 1.15(h), RPC, Rule 407, SCACR.Â  In response to
  inquires from ODC, respondent represented that he had in fact written the
  requisite letter to his bank shortly after it became a requirement on October
  1, 2005, but did not mail the letter to the bank and only discovered he had not
  done so when he found the letter in preparation of a response to inquires from
  ODC.Â   
Respondent did not review cancelled
  checks from his trust account until he received notice of the overdraft from
  his title insurance carrier in June 2006.Â  Respondent did not review the
  cancelled checks from his trust account notwithstanding the requirements of
  Rule 1.15(a), RPC, and Rule 417, SCACR, which mandate monthly reconciliation of
  bank statements with trust account records. Â Â Respondent recognizes that his
  failure to fully comply with the published directives of the Court and his
  failure to more closely supervise Knowles enabled Knowles to commit
  embezzlement and when compliance with the directives would have revealed the
  checks she was forging and the resulting shortages in respondentâ€™s trust
  account.Â   
Respondent admits that, as a result of
  his failure to comply with Rule 1.15, RPC, and Rule 417, SCACR, he did not
  provide clients with competent or diligent representation.Â  Further, he admits
  he allowed monies belonging to one client to be used for the benefit of another
  as a result of the necessity of â€œlappingâ€ of monies in his trust account due to
  shortages caused by Knowlesâ€™ embezzlement.Â Â   
In mitigation, respondent has been
  continuously engaged in the practice of law in this state since 1995 and has
  not previously been the subject of any disciplinary complaint.Â  Respondent
  self-reported this matter to ODC and has fully cooperated with ODCâ€™s inquiries
  and efforts to conclude this matter expeditiously.Â  During a portion of the
  period in which the embezzlement occurred, respondent was dealing with a
  serious personal health problem and the death of three close family members.Â 
 
Further, with the best interests of his
  clients in mind, respondent had the foresight to:Â  1) obtain fidelity insurance
  coverage in the amount of $100,000 (which has been paid in full towards the
  amounts embezzled); 2) deposit $43,000 of his personal funds into the trust
  account to cover the shortages caused by Knowlesâ€™ embezzlement;[3] and 3) obtain through errors and omissions coverage and insured closing
  arrangements with his title company ample funds available to compensate all
  victims of Knowlesâ€™ embezzlement, except for possibly himself.Â  Â Â 
Since discovering the embezzlement,
  respondent has implemented additional office management procedures designed to
  more effectively safeguard his clientsâ€™ funds and to more closely supervise his
  staff.Â  Respondent represents he is how fully complying with the requirements
  of Rule 1.15(h), RPC, and Rule 417, SCACR, and will make every effort to strictly
  comply in the future.Â  Further, respondent represents that his trust account is
  now balanced.Â  ODC believes these representations to be correct.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
 
LAW
Respondent admits that by his misconduct
  he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct,
  Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation);
  Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence in representing client); Rule
  1.15(a) (lawyer shall safekeep client funds);Â  Rule 1.15(g) (lawyer shall not
  use entrusted property for benefit of any person other than the owner of the
  property); Rule 1.15(h) (lawyer shall file written directive with financial
  institution to report to Commission on Lawyer Conduct when instrument is
  returned against trust account for insufficient funds); Rule 5.3(a) (lawyer
  shall make reasonable efforts to ensure firm has measures giving reasonable
  assurances that non-lawyer employeeâ€™s conduct is compatible with professional
  obligations of lawyer); Rule 5.3(b) (lawyer having direct supervisory authority
  over non-lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to ensure non-lawyerâ€™s conduct is
  compatible with professional obligations of lawyer); Rule 5.3(c)(2) (lawyer
  shall be responsible for conduct of non-lawyer if he has supervisory authority
  over non-lawyer and knows of the non-lawyerâ€™s conduct at a time when its
  consequences can be avoided but fails to take remedial action); and Rule 8.4(a)
  (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional
  Conduct).Â  In addition, respondent admits the he violated the recordkeeping
  provisions of Rule 417, SCACR.Â  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct
  constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary
  Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for
  discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â Â Â Â Â   
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct
  warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for
  Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES
  and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] The check had been written to pay off a first
  lien in connection with a real estate transaction in which respondent had
  served as the closing attorney.
[2] Respondent advised the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Office of this matter.Â  On
  June 26, 2006, Knowles was charged with Breach of Trust with Fraudulent Intent
  greater than a value of $5,000.Â   
[3] Respondent has lost approximately $28,000 in
  embezzled money which represented his portion of title insurance premiums.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter
      of Alex J. Newton, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26402
Submitted November 6, 2007 - Filed
  December 10, 2007
DISBARRED


	
		
			
				Lesley M. Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Assistant Deputy
  Attorney General, and Robert E. Bogan, both of Columbia, for Office of
  Disciplinary Counsel.
				Desa A. Ballard, of West Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21,
  RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and
  consents to disbarment.Â  Respondent requests that the date of disbarment be
  retroactive to the date of interim suspension.[1]Â 
  We accept the Agreement and disbar respondent from the practice of law in this
  state, retroactive to March 22, 2006.Â  The facts, as set forth in the
  Agreement, are as follows.
Facts
Between
  May 1, 2002, and March 1, 2004, respondent, who was engaged in the business of
  closing residential mortgage loans, closed certain transactions as part of a
  two-transaction â€œflip,â€ using loan proceeds intended to fund only the second
  transaction to fund both.Â  Respondent also lent funds from his trust account to
  one or more â€œstraw menâ€ purchasers on certain occasions to effect these
  transactions.Â  In connection with these â€œflipâ€ transactions, respondent
  prepared HUD-1 closing statements containing false representations and/or
  omissions that were material to the transactions.Â  Respondent also permitted
  borrowers to certify that the properties purchased would be owner-occupied as a
  primary residence, a condition for loan approval, when he knew that was not
  true.Â   
Respondent submitted the false certifications and HUD-1 closing
  statements to lenders through the United States Mail and through private and
  commercial carriers.Â  Respondent was charged with one count of conspiracy to
  commit mail fraud in violation of 18 U.S.C. Â§ 371, a felony under federal law
  and a serious crime under Rule 2(aa), Rule 413, SCACR.Â  Respondent pled guilty
  in federal court to the charged offense and was sentenced to forty-one monthsâ€™
  imprisonment.Â  The indictment and plea were related to one of the closings
  mentioned hereinabove.
Law
Respondent admits that, by his misconduct, he has violated the
  following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:
  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 1.4
  (lawyer shall consult with the
  client about any relevant limitation on the lawyerâ€™s conduct when the lawyer
  knows the client expects assistance not permitted by the Rules of Professional
  Conduct or other law); Rule 1.8 (lawyer shall not provide financial
  assistance to a client in connection with pending or contemplated litigation); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall hold property of clients in the lawyerâ€™s
  possession in connection with a representation separate from the lawyerâ€™s own
  property); Rule 4.1 (in the course
  of representing a client a lawyer shall not knowingly make a false statement of
  material fact or law to a third person or fail to disclose a material fact when
  disclosure is necessary to avoid assisting a criminal or fraudulent act by a
  client); Rule 8.4(a) (it is
  professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional
  Conduct); Rule 8.4(b) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to commit a
  criminal act that reflects adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness
  or fitness as a lawyer in other respects); Rule 8.4(c) (it is professional
  misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct involving moral turpitude); Rule
  8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct
  involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (it
  is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct that is
  prejudicial to the administration of justice).
Respondent
  further admits his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the
  following provisions of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule
  413, SCACR: Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be a ground for discipline for lawyer to
  violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 7(a)(4) (be convicted of a crime of moral turpitude or a
  serious crime); Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be a ground for
  discipline for a lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute the
  administration of justice, bring the courts or legal profession into disrepute,
  or demonstrating an unfitness to practice law); and Rule 7(a)(6) (it shall be a
  ground for discipline for a lawyer to violate the oath of office).Â  In
  addition, respondent admits his misconduct violated Rule 417, SCACR.
      


Conclusion
We
  accept the Agreement for
  Discipline by Consent and disbar
  respondent from the practice of law in this state retroactive to March 22, 2006.Â 
  Within fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an
  affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30 of
  Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender his Certificate of Admission to the
  Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.
DISBARRED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

  of this Court dated March 22, 2006.Â  In the Matter of Newton, 368 S.C.

  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel have entered into an
  Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413,
  SCACR.Â  In the Agreement,
  respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a range of sanctions from a confidential
  admonition to a sixty day suspension pursuant to Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413,
  SCACR.Â  Respondent requests any suspension be made retroactive to the date of his

accept the agreement and suspend respondent from the practice of law in this 
state for sixty days, retroactive to the date of his interim suspension.
FACTS
Respondent,
  who was a public defender at the time, failed to appear for a case and another
  public defender picked the jury on his behalf.Â  Respondent appeared for trial
  the following day, but asked for a continuance on the grounds that he had been
  ill and was unprepared.Â  While respondent maintains he informed the solicitor
  he was ill, he failed to notify his client of the trial in the belief the case would
  be continued.Â  The trial judge found respondent in contempt and ordered
  respondent to pay the cost of the jury and write a written apology to the
  jurors.Â  Respondent fully complied with the order.Â  Respondent contends he did
  not notify the Office of Disciplinary Counsel of the finding of contempt
  because the sanctioning judge found respondentâ€™s conduct did not amount to an
  ethical violation, a contention the Office of Disciplinary Counsel states it
  has no reason to doubt since the matter was not reported by the sanctioning
  judge.
In
  this matter and three other matters, respondent failed to respond to the Office
  of Disciplinary Counselâ€™s initial inquiries, Treacy letters,[2] and notices of full investigation.Â 
  Respondent maintains he failed to respond to the Office of Disciplinary Counsel
  because he was suffering from depression.Â  Respondent, who has been diagnosed
  as suffering from depression, has sought help from Lawyers Helping Lawyers, has
  signed a monitoring agreement with them and has been seeing a psychiatrist
  recommended by them as well.Â  In addition, respondent has since met with the
  Office of Disciplinary Counsel and provided information regarding the
  complaints against him, including the three additional complaints, which the
  Office of Disciplinary Counsel states it would have recommended dismissing if
  it had received the requested information from respondent.Â  Finally, respondent
  has fully cooperated with the Office of Disciplinary Counsel since being placed
  on interim suspension.
Law
Respondent
  admits that by his conduct he has violated the following provisions of the
  Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (a lawyer shall
  provide competent representation to a client); Rule 1.3 (a lawyer shall act
  with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (a
  lawyer shall explain a matter to the extent reasonably necessary to permit the
  client to make informed decisions regarding the representation, keep the client
  reasonably informed about the status of the matter, and promptly comply with
  reasonable requests for information); and Rule 8.1(b) (a lawyer in connection
  with a disciplinary matter shall not knowingly
  fail to respond to a lawful demand for information from a disciplinary
  authority).
Respondent also admits that he has violated the
  following provisions of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule
  413, SCACR:Â  Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to
  violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 7(a)(3) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to
  fail to respond to a lawful demand from a disciplinary authority including a
  request for a response); and Rule 7(a)(6) (it shall be a ground for discipline
  for a lawyer to violate the oath of office taken upon admission to practice law
  in this state).
Conclusion
We find a sixty day suspension is the appropriate sanction for
  respondentâ€™s misconduct.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline
  by Consent and suspend respondent from the practice of law for sixty days,
  retroactive to the date of his interim suspension.Â  Within fifteen days of the
  date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of
  Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE
  SUSPENSION.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

  name as a witness on the mortgage, no one else was present to function as a

  as the second witness to the mortgage and as personally witnessing the clientâ€™s

  the client signed the mortgage.Â  Respondent notarized the paralegalâ€™s signature
  and statement even though he knew it was false.Â  The mortgage was subsequently

  the course of the investigation by the Office of Disciplinary Counsel, in which

  refused to conduct closings on several occasions due to the lack of a second
  witness.
Law
Respondent
  admits that by his conduct he has violated the following provisions of the
  Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (a lawyer shall
  provide competent representation to a client); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional
  misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); and Rule
  8.4(d)(it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit
  or misrepresentation).
Respondent also admits that he has violated Rule
  7(a)(1) of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, by
  violating the Rules of Professional Conduct.
Conclusion
We find a sixty day suspension is the appropriate sanction for
  respondentâ€™s misconduct.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by
  Consent and suspend respondent from the practice of law for sixty days.[1]Â  Within fifteen days of the date of
  this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court
  showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 

[1] The Office of Disciplinary Counsel has requested an
  attorney to protect clientsâ€™ interests be appointed, pursuant to Rule 31, RLDE,
  Rule 413, SCACR, if a definite suspension is imposed.Â  We have granted that
  request by separate order.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				James A. Smith, Petitioner
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Colleton County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26405
Submitted September 20, 2007 - Filed
  December 10, 2007Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate
  Defender Aileen P. Clare, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense,
  Division of Appellate Defense, Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Jeanette
  Van Ginhoven, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  Petitioner was convicted of
  two counts of murder.Â  After his convictions were affirmed on direct appeal,
  Petitioner brought this action seeking post-conviction relief (PCR) on the
  grounds both his trial counsel and appellate counsel were ineffective.Â  We
  granted certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s denial of relief to Petitioner.Â 
  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On June 1, 1997,
  Gwen Utsey reported to the Colleton County Sheriffâ€™s Department that her
  sister-in-law, Hattie Mae Yates, and Yatesâ€™s two-week-old daughter, Moesha, had
  been missing for one day.Â  On June 5, 1997, deputies discovered Hattie Maeâ€™s
  abandoned car in a wooded area near the home of Petitioner and his girlfriend,
  Darlene Winningham.Â  On June 16, 1997, Winningham gave a statement to Detective
  Steve Bazzle in which she claimed Petitioner had killed Hattie Mae and Moesha
  Yates.Â  Winningham informed Detective Bazzle where the bodies were located, but
  denied that she had been involved in the murders or the subsequent â€œcover up.â€Â 
  Based on this information, investigators with the sheriffâ€™s department
  recovered the bodies in a make-shift grave.Â   
Upon discovering that Winningham
  had identified him as the primary suspect, Petitioner gave a lengthy statement
  to Detective Bazzle. Â According to Petitioner, Hattie Mae, his crack cocaine
  supplier, drove to his home in Cottageville on the afternoon of May 31, 1997,
  to discuss a crack cocaine transaction.Â  As Hattie Mae waited in her car with
  Moesha, Petitioner went inside the home to retrieve cash for the transaction.Â 
  Petitioner claimed that Winningham â€œflipped outâ€ and began shooting when he
  attempted to pay Hattie Mae with $100 that he had taken from Winningham.Â 
  Petitioner then stated he attempted to cover up the crime by hiding Hattie
  Maeâ€™s car, burying the bodies, and disposing of the rifle.Â  Following his
  statement, Petitioner led detectives to a pond where he had hidden the murder
  weapon.Â   
Both Petitioner and Winningham were
  charged with the murders.Â  At Petitionerâ€™s trial, Winningham testified for the
  State.Â  Winningham testified that on May 31, 2007, at around 3:00 p.m., her
  friend drove her and her three children home after taking them to the grocery
  store.Â  According to Winningham, Petitioner came out of the house and told her
  to take the children to their grandfatherâ€™s home.Â  When Winningham returned
  home, Hattie Mae came to the Petitionerâ€™s home and pulled around to the back
  porch.Â  Winningham stated she heard a â€œgun go offâ€ and Petitioner yelled for
  her to check the road to see if there were any cars coming toward the home.Â 
  Winningham claimed Petitioner then drove off in Hattie Maeâ€™s car through the
  back yard into a field.Â  Petitioner returned and requested Winninghamâ€™s help
  after he struck a tree.Â  Winningham stated that she saw Hattie Mae lying dead
  on the ground and Moesha lying still in the car seat.Â  Winningham testified
  that over the course of the next three days Petitioner returned to the woods
  several times and engaged the assistance of Kenneth Dale Bazzle, Jr.,
  Winninghamâ€™s oldest son, to empty and burn the contents of Hattie Maeâ€™s car, to
  hide the car in the country, and to bury the victimsâ€™ bodies.Â  Kenneth Dale
  Bazzle corroborated Winninghamâ€™s testimony.Â  Additionally, Kenneth Dale stated
  that Petitioner told him that he had killed Hattie Mae and Moesha.
Petitioner testified in his
  defense.Â  Although he recounted a similar sequence of events as that described
  in the Stateâ€™s case, he adamantly denied that he shot Hattie Mae and Moesha.Â  He
  maintained that Winningham became enraged and fired into Hattie Maeâ€™s car after
  he handed $100 to Hattie Mae for crack cocaine.  
The trial court submitted two
  counts of murder to the jury.Â  The jury found Petitioner guilty of both counts,
  and the trial court sentenced Petitioner to life imprisonment without parole
  and a consecutive thirty-year term.Â   
After his
  convictions were affirmed on direct appeal, Petitioner filed for PCR.Â  In his
  application, Petitioner asserted he was being held unlawfully because:Â  (1) his
  convictions and sentences for two counts of murder were unconstitutional in
  that they constituted a violation of the Double Jeopardy Clause; (2) the
  solicitor made improper comments during his closing argument; (3)
  after-discovered evidence required reversal of his convictions and sentences;
  and (4) his trial counsel and appellate counsel were ineffective.Â 
  Subsequently, Petitioner amended his petition to include an allegation that
  after-discovered evidence revealed one of the jurors knew him from being
  incarcerated in the same facility and shared this information with the other
  members of the jury.  
The
  PCR judge held a hearing on the petition.Â  At the hearing, Petitioner testified
  and presented the testimony of Juror Floyd Walling as well as John D. Bryan,
  Petitionerâ€™s trial counsel.Â Â  The PCR judge also permitted Petitioner to
  supplement the record with the statement and affidavit of Kenneth Dale Bazzle
  in order to compare the statement with Bazzleâ€™s trial testimony.  
The
  PCR judge denied Petitioner relief and dismissed his application with
  prejudice.Â  The PCR judge held trial counsel was not ineffective for failing
  to:Â  (1) request specific jury voir dire questions which would
  have uncovered Juror Wallingâ€™s prior relationship with Petitioner; (2) object
  to the solicitorâ€™s improper closing argument; and (3) object to a portion of
  Winninghamâ€™s testimony.Â  Additionally, the PCR judge found appellate counsel
  was not ineffective in presenting Petitionerâ€™s direct appeal to the Court of
  Appeals.Â  Petitioner appeals from this order.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A
  defendant has the right to the effective assistance of counsel under the Sixth
  Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).Â  â€œThere is a strong presumption that counsel rendered
  adequate assistance and exercised reasonable professional judgment in making
  all significant decisions in the case.â€Â  Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318,
  331, 642 S.E.2d 590, 596 (2007), cert.denied, 128 S. Ct. 370 (2007).Â Â  
 
In a
  PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he is
  entitled to relief.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d
  514, 517 (2000).Â  In order to prove that counsel was ineffective, the PCR
  applicant must show that: (1) counselâ€™s performance was deficient; and (2) there
  is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s errors, the result of the
  trial would have been different.Â  Id. (citing Strickland v.
    Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984)).Â  â€œA reasonable probability is a
  probability sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcome of the trial.â€Â  Ard,
  372 S.C. at 331, 642 S.E.2d at 596. â€œFurthermore, when a defendantâ€™s conviction
  is challenged, â€˜the question is whether there is a reasonable probability that,
  absent the errors, the fact finder would have had a reasonable doubt respecting
  guilt.â€™â€ Id. (quoting Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 695 (1984)).
â€œThis
  Court gives great deference to the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s
  findings of fact and conclusions of law.â€Â  Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C.
  365, 368, 610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005).Â  A PCR courtâ€™s findings will be upheld on
  appeal if there is â€œany evidence of probative value sufficient to support
  them.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThis Court will reverse the PCR courtâ€™s decision when it
  is controlled by an
  error of law.â€Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 651, 594 S.E.2d 462,
  465 (2004).
DISCUSSION
I.
A.
Petitioner first asserts the PCR judge erred in failing to find
  the presence of Juror Floyd Walling, with whom he had been incarcerated prior
  to trial, constituted a per se violation of his due process right
  to a fair and impartial jury.Â   
During voir dire, the trial judge asked the members of the jury pool
  whether any member was â€œrelated by blood or marriageâ€ to Petitioner or was a
  â€œclose personal friend.â€Â  Walling did not respond to this question.Â  Before
  Walling was seated on the jury, his trial counsel had three remaining
  peremptory challenges.  
While
  serving his sentence for the two counts of murder, Petitioner discovered that
  he and Juror Walling had been incarcerated together at the Colleton County   Detention Center in 1997.Â  Petitioner made the connection when his cellmate
  noticed that Floyd Walling, the cellmateâ€™s cousin, was listed as a juror on
  Petitionerâ€™s trial transcript.Â  Petitioner remembered Walling after the cellmate
  told him that Walling was also known as â€œRum Gully.â€Â  At the PCR hearing,
  Petitioner testified he did not recognize Walling as the man he knew in prison
  because Walling had shaved his beard and was not wearing prison attire.Â 
  Additionally, Petitioner was not aware of Wallingâ€™s given name, but rather,
  knew him as â€œRum Gully.â€Â  Although he was unable to produce documentation,
  Petitioner claimed that he and Walling had altercations while in jail, which
  included incidents where Petitioner threw urine on Walling and struck him with
  a mop.Â Â   
Petitioner
  presented Walling as a witness at the PCR hearing.Â  Walling testified he was
  detained several times for failing to pay child support.Â  While serving this
  time, Walling was assigned to laundry detail.Â  In this capacity, Walling
  encountered Petitioner when he delivered clean clothing to him.Â  Despite this
  interaction, Walling testified that he and Petitioner never spoke to one
  another.Â  He further testified there was an incident where an inmate threw
  urine and feces on him, but he did not know who did it and did not suspect that
  Petitioner was responsible.Â  Walling admitted that while in jail he heard that
  Petitioner was â€œaccused of murder, but that was yet to be proven.â€Â  Walling
  stated that he did recognize Petitioner at the time of trial as the person who
  was being detained in the Colleton County Detention Center in 1997. Â Although
  he did not disclose this information to the trial judge, Walling claimed that
  had the judge inquired whether he knew Petitioner he would have answered
  affirmatively and â€œasked them to dismiss [him] off the jury.â€
In
  response to questioning by the PCR judge, Walling denied having any bias or
  prejudice against Petitioner.Â  Walling, however, admitted he had told the other
  jurors that he had been incarcerated with Petitioner and that Petitioner â€œwas
  accused of murder, but heâ€™s got to be proven before heâ€™s [convicted].â€  
Petitionerâ€™s
  trial counsel testified that had he known that Walling and Petitioner had been
  incarcerated together, he â€œwould have probably used a peremptory strike.â€ 
 
In
  his order, the PCR judge found â€œWallingâ€™s testimony that he had no preexisting
  bias against the [Petitioner] to be highly credible.â€Â  In light of the evidence
  presented at the hearing, the judge believed Walling â€œacted as a fair and
  impartial jurorâ€ and that Petitioner failed to show that Walling prejudiced the
  other jury members by informing them that the two had been incarcerated
  together.Â  The judge reasoned that the jury was â€œclearly aware that [Petitioner]
  was incarcerated at the time of trial but had not been convicted of the crimes
  with which he was charged.â€Â Â   
Based
  on the foregoing facts, Petitioner contends Juror Wallingâ€™s presence on the
  jury was a per se violation of due process on the ground â€œthe
  circumstances of their relationship created a â€˜presumption of bias.â€™â€[1]Â  Specifically, Petitioner asserts the information revealed by
  Walling to the other jury members â€œcould have had no other effect than to fix
  the image of petitioner as an inmate, hence a criminal, in the jurorsâ€™ minds.â€Â  
 
â€œ[A]
  criminal defendant has no right to a trial by any particular jury, but only a
  right to a trial by a competent and impartial jury.â€Â  Palacio v. State,
  333 S.C. 506, 517, 511 S.E.2d 62, 68 (1999).Â  â€œâ€˜[I]n order to fully safeguard this protection, it is required
  that the jury render its verdict free from outside influences of whatever kind
  and nature.â€™â€Â  State v. Bryant, 354 S.C. 390, 395, 581 S.E.2d 157, 160
  (2003)(quoting State v. Cameron, 311 S.C. 204, 207, 428 S.E.2d 10, 12
  (Ct. App. 1993)).Â   
â€œTo
  protect both partiesâ€™ right to an impartial jury, the
  trial judge must ask potential jurors whether they are aware of any bias or
  prejudice against a party.â€Â  State v. Woods, 345 S.C. 583, 587, 550
  S.E.2d 282, 284 (2001).Â  â€œWhen a juror conceals information inquired into
  during voir dire, a new trial is required only when the court finds the
  juror intentionally concealed the information, and that the information
  concealed would have supported a challenge for cause or would have been a
  material factor in the use of the partyâ€™s peremptory challenges.â€ Id.Â  â€œWhere a juror, without justification, fails to disclose a relationship, it may
  be inferred, nothing to the contrary appearing, that the juror is not impartial. On the other
  hand, where the failure to disclose is innocent, no such inference may be
  drawn.â€Â  Id. at 586-87, 550 S.E.2d at 284.
â€œDetermining
  whether a jurorâ€™s failure to respond to a voir dire question amounts to
  intentional concealment is a â€˜fact
  intensive determination that must be made on a case-by-case basis.â€™â€ State
    v. Guillebeaux, 362 S.C. 270, 274, 607 S.E.2d 99, 101-02 (Ct. App.
  2004)(quoting State v. Sparkman, 358 S.C. 491, 496, 596 S.E.2d 375, 377
  (2004)). â€œIntentional
  concealment occurs â€˜when the question presented to the jury on voir dire is
  reasonably comprehensible to the average juror and the subject of the inquiry
  is of such significance that the jurorâ€™s failure to respond is unreasonable.â€™â€ Id. â€œConcealment is considered unintentional where the voir dire question posed is
  ambiguous or incomprehensible to the average juror or where â€˜the subject of the
  inquiry is insignificant or so far removed in time that the jurorâ€™s failure to
  respond is reasonable under the circumstances.â€™â€Â  Id.  
Applying the above-outlined principles to the facts of the instant
  case, we find the PCR judge properly denied Petitioner relief on this ground.Â 
  Here, it was reasonable for Juror Walling to remain silent when asked during voir dire whether any member of the jury pool was â€œrelated by blood or
  marriage or a close personal friend of [Petitioner].â€ Â At the PCR hearing,
  Juror Walling testified that he and Petitioner were not close friends.Â 
  Petitioner corroborated Wallingâ€™s testimony when he acknowledged that he did
  not know Walling very well. Â Juror Walling also testified that he did not have
  any bias or prejudice against Petitioner, and he and the other members of the
  jury held the State to its burden of proof before finding Petitioner guilty of
  the two murder charges. Â 
Based on Juror Wallingâ€™s testimony at the hearing, we believe that
  Walling did not intentionally conceal the existence of his prior relationship
  with Petitioner.Â  See Guillebeaux, 362 S.C. at 274-75, 607 S.E.2d
  at 101-02 (holding juror did not intentionally conceal existence of social
  relationship with the Stateâ€™s chief witness and, thus, trial judge did not
  abuse his discretion in denying defendantâ€™s motion for a new trial); State
    v. Galbreath, 359 S.C. 398, 403-04, 597 S.E.2d 845 847-48 (Ct. App. 2004) (finding
  juror did not intentionally conceal that juror knew the victimâ€™s mother and
  that jurorâ€™s brother-in-law rented land from someone in victimâ€™s extended
  family where juror accurately answered voir dire question posed
  and the alleged relationships did not amount to close personal friends or
  business associates with any of the witnesses); see also Sparkman,
  358 S.C. at 496-97, 596 S.E.2d at 376-77 (concluding no intentional concealment
  where the judge asked on voir dire whether anyone had been the
  victim of a â€œserious crimeâ€ and seated juror did not immediately recall that he
  had been a victim of a crime forty years earlier and was not sure if the crime
  constituted a â€œseriousâ€ one).Â   
Furthermore, because the disposition of this issue essentially
  involves a credibility determination as to whether Juror Walling intentionally
  concealed his prior relationship with Petitioner, we defer to the PCR judgeâ€™s
  findings.Â  The PCR judge specifically found Juror Wallingâ€™s testimony to be
  â€œhighly credible.â€Â  Solomon v. State, 313 S.C. 526, 529, 443 S.E.2d 540,
  542 (1994) (stating the Court gives great deference to a PCR courtâ€™s findings
  when matters of credibility are involved); State v. Loftis, 232 S.C. 35,
  45, 100 S.E.2d 671, 675 (1957) (declining to interfere with trial judgeâ€™s
  discretion in matter concerning jury because trial judge has the opportunity to
  consider credibility of jurors).Â  Accordingly, we affirm the judgeâ€™s holding
  that Petitioner did not suffer a per se violation of his due
  process right to a fair and impartial jury.
B.
In the
  alternative, Petitioner asserts he should receive a new trial because trial
  counsel was ineffective for not requesting appropriate voir dire questions.Â  Petitioner contends that had counsel asked the court to â€œinquire
  about social contacts beyond â€˜close, personalâ€™ friendships and business
  associations,â€ Juror Walling would have come forward and counsel could have
  made a motion to remove him for cause or exercise a peremptory strike.Â   
Without
  reiterating the above analysis, there is evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s
  decision that Petitioner â€œfailed to make the requisite showing of prejudice
  resulting from Counselâ€™s alleged deficiency in regards to additional jury voir
  dire.â€Â  Juror Walling testified that he and the other members of the jury held
  the State to its burden of proof before finding Petitioner guilty.Â 
  Additionally, Juror Walling stated that â€œit was a while there before they could
  convince me that heâ€™s the one [that] done it.â€ Â Given Juror Walling and the
  other members of the jury adhered to the requisite standard of proof before
  convicting Petitioner, we find any alleged error by trial counsel did not
  result in a violation of Petitionerâ€™s right to a fair and impartial jury.Â  Â Thus,
  the PCR judge properly denied Petitioner relief on this ground.
II.
Next, Petitioner argues the PCR judge erred in finding trial
  counsel was not ineffective for failing to object to certain portions of the
  solicitorâ€™s closing argument on due process grounds as well as Rule 22 of the
  South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure.Â  Specifically, Petitioner contends
  trial counsel was ineffective for not objecting to the solicitorâ€™s comments on
  constitutional due process grounds â€œrather than mere rule violations.â€  
At
  trial, there was conflicting testimony as to whether Petitioner or his
  girlfriend, Darlene Winningham, shot Hattie Mae Yates and her infant daughter.Â 
  In response to this testimony, the solicitor stated during his closing
  argument:

	I
  know that [Petitioner] was surprised when those children got there at 3:00 or
  3:30, and that he sent them off.Â  I know that he thought Hattie Mae Yates - - -
	* *
  *
	And,
  God only knows, I donâ€™t know what the motive for that is, and his Honor will
  charge you that the State is not required to prove a motive.Â  I donâ€™t know
  whether they got mad with each other or what, but I know it happened.Â  I know
  that the person on the porch didnâ€™t kill them. 
	* *
  *
	You
  know, Hattie Mae Yates - there may come a time in life where your life doesnâ€™t
  mean much, and I canâ€™t tell you that Hattieâ€™s did, but I can tell you one
  thing.Â  That little girl that was sitting in that car seat she ainâ€™t never done
  anything to anybody.Â  Never in her life has she ever said a bad word.Â  And I
  know she is dead, and sheâ€™s dead at the hands of [Petitioner], and, for that,
  you need to convict him for murder.Â  

To
  each of these comments, trial counsel interposed an objection and moved for a
  mistrial based on Rule 22 of the South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure.[2]Â  The trial judge denied the motion for a mistrial.Â  In reaching
  this decision, the judge did not believe â€œthat there was such egregious abuse
  as would suggest that the Solicitor ha[d] invaded the juryâ€™s province of
  deciding whether or not the facts and inferences drawn therefrom would support
  a verdict.â€Â   
At
  the PCR hearing, trial counsel explained that he objected on the basis of Rule
  22 because he â€œdidnâ€™t really see a huge difference between the constitutional
  rule and the criminal procedural rule.Â  Itâ€™s both preventative and both exist
  for the same reason in order to give him a fair trial.Â  Thatâ€™s the reason for
  both rules.â€Â  The PCR judge also apparently did not see a distinction between
  an objection based on Rule 22 and due process grounds.Â  In denying Petitioner
  relief on this ground, the judge found that â€œCounsel cannot be said to have
  failed to make every reasonable effort to protect the [Petitionerâ€™s] right to a
  fair trial.â€Â  The judge noted that counsel made â€œtimely objections to the
  solicitorâ€™s comments where appropriateâ€ and â€œmoved for a mistrial on the ground
  that the solicitorâ€™s comments constituted a violation of professional ethics.â€Â 
  The judge concluded that â€œgiven the overwhelming evidence of [Petitionerâ€™s]
  guilt of the crimes with which he was charged, the [Petitioner] has failed to
  make the requisite showing of prejudice resulting from any alleged deficiency.â€
 
Despite
  the PCR judgeâ€™s failure to specifically rule on the distinction made by
  Petitioner in terms of a Rule 22 objection versus an objection based on
  constitutional due process grounds, we believe his ultimate decision that trial
  counsel was not ineffective was correct and is supported by the record.
As a
  threshold matter, trial counsel was not deficient in failing to specifically
  object on constitutional grounds.Â  As we view Rule 22, we believe it was
  promulgated on the concepts of due process and fundamental fairness.Â  Our research
  has not revealed any cases which analyze Rule 22.Â  Therefore, Rule 22 is not
  considered distinctly different from an objection based on due process
  principles.Â Â  Accordingly, we hold trial counselâ€™s objection based on Rule 22
  was sufficient to encompass any due process claims alleged by Petitioner.Â  
 
Even
  assuming that trial counsel was deficient in not interposing a specific
  objection based on constitutional grounds, Petitioner was not prejudiced by his
  failure to do so.Â  We find that any impropriety in the solicitorâ€™s closing
  argument was not sufficient to warrant the grant of a new trial.
A solicitorâ€™s closing argument must be carefully tailored so
  as not to appeal to the personal biases of the jury.Â  State v. Copeland,
  321 S.C. 318, 324, 468 S.E.2d 620, 624 (1996).Â  The Stateâ€™s closing arguments
  must be confined to evidence in the record and the reasonable inferences that
  may be drawn from the evidence.Â  Id.Â  â€œA solicitor has a right to state
  his version of the testimony and to comment on the weight to be given such
  testimony.â€Â  Randall v. State, 356 S.C. 639, 642, 591 S.E.2d 608, 610
  (2004).Â  However, â€œ[a] solicitor may not vouch for the credibility of a Stateâ€™s
  witness based on personal knowledge or other information outside the record.â€Â  Matthews
    v. State, 350 S.C. 272, 276, 565 S.E.2d 766, 768 (2002).
â€œOn
  appeal, the appellate court will view the alleged impropriety of the
  solicitorâ€™s argument in the context of the entire record, including whether the
  trial judgeâ€™s instructions adequately cured the improper argument and whether
  there is overwhelming evidence of the defendantâ€™s guilt.â€Â  Simmons v. State,
  331 S.C. 333, 338, 503 S.E.2d 164, 166 (1998). â€œImproper comments do not
  automatically require reversal if they are not prejudicial to the defendant,
  and the appellant has the burden of proving he did not receive a fair trial
  because of the alleged improper argument.â€Â  Humphries v. State, 351 S.C.
  362, 373, 570 S.E.2d 160, 166 (2002).Â  â€œThe relevant question is whether the
  solicitorâ€™s comments so infected the trial with unfairness as to make the
  resulting conviction a denial of due process.â€ Id.; see State
    v. Hornsby, 326 S.C. 121, 129, 484 S.E.2d 869, 873 (1997)(â€œA denial of due process occurs when a defendant in a criminal trial is
  denied the fundamental fairness essential to the concept of justice.â€).Â 
  Furthermore, a trial judge is allowed discretion in dealing with the range and propriety of closing argument to the
  jury, and rulings on such matters will not be disturbed absent an abuse of
  discretion.Â  State v. Patterson, 324 S.C. 5, 17, 482 S.E.2d 760, 766
  (1997).  
In
  the instant case, the solicitorâ€™s comments were confined to facts established
  during trial and, in the context of the entire record, were not so egregious as
  to have â€œinfected the trial with unfairness as to make the resulting conviction
  a denial of due process.â€Â  Von Dohlen v. State, 360 S.C. 598, 609, 602
  S.E.2d 738, 744 (2004), cert. denied, 544 U.S. 943 (2005).Â  Although the
  solicitor improperly used the pronoun â€œIâ€ in his closing argument, these
  comments were limited and did not recur throughout his argument.Â  Furthermore,
  there was also overwhelming evidence of Petitionerâ€™s guilt.Â  See State
    v. McFadden, 318 S.C. 404, 416, 458 S.E.2d 61, 68 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding
  the solicitorâ€™s comments did not infect the trial with unfairness to the extent
  that his conviction was a denial of due process where there was ample evidence
  of guilt in the record).Â  Finally, the trial judge charged the jury that â€œ[y]ou
  must not consider as evidence any statement of counsel made during the trial,â€
  and instructed the jury members regarding their duty to â€œpass upon the credibility
  or believability of the witnesses.â€ Â These instructions were sufficient to cure
  any possible prejudice caused by the solicitorâ€™s comments.Â  Therefore, we do
  not believe there was a reasonable probability that the result of the trial
  would have been different had trial counsel objected on due process grounds.Â  
 
III.
Finally, Petitioner argues the PCR judge erred in failing to find
  that appellate counsel was ineffective for briefing the solicitorâ€™s closing
  argument issue as a due process violation rather than raising the Rule 22 procedural
  issue that was presented at trial.Â   
In his brief to
  the Court of Appeals, Petitionerâ€™s appellate counsel argued â€œthe [trial] court
  erred in violation of due process of law when it repeatedly permitted the solicitor
  to inject his personal opinion that appellant was guilty into a case where the
  key witness had given grossly inconsistent information about the case.â€Â  In an
  opinion pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, the Court of Appeals affirmed
  Petitionerâ€™s convictions on error preservation grounds because the
  constitutional issue raised on appeal had not been raised at trial.Â  State v. James Smith, Op. No. 2002-UP-320 (S.C. Ct. App. filed May 3, 2002).
In his order, the PCR judge found appellate counsel was not ineffective.Â  In reaching this
  decision, the judge noted that appellate counsel had filed a brief pursuant to Anders
    v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and thus, Petitionerâ€™s case had
  received full review by the Court of Appeals.Â  Because appellate counsel filed
  a regular appeal and not an Anders brief on behalf of Petitioner, the
  PCR judge clearly erred in his findings.Â  This error, however, does not warrant
  reversal given that Petitioner is unable to show that any alleged deficiency in
  appellate counselâ€™s performance would have resulted in a different outcome on
  appeal.  
A
  PCR applicant has the burden of proving appellate counselâ€™s performance was
  deficient.Â  Anderson v. State, 354 S.C. 431, 434, 581 S.E.2d 834,
  835 (2003).Â  â€œAlthough appellate counsel is required to provide effective
  assistance of counsel, â€˜appellate counsel is not required to raise every
  nonfrivolous issue that is presented by the record.â€™â€Â  Tisdale v. State,
  357 S.C. 474, 476, 594 S.E.2d 166, 167 (2004), cert. denied, 543 U.S.
  845 (2004) (quoting Thrift v. State, 302 S.C. 535, 539, 397 S.E.2d 523,
  526 (1990)).
Because trial
  counsel objected to the solicitorâ€™s closing argument pursuant to Rule 22, appellate
  counsel was remiss in failing to brief the specific issue raised at trial.Â  Petitioner,
  however, cannot establish that he was prejudiced by this deficiency.Â  As
  previously discussed trial counselâ€™s objection based on Rule 22 encompassed any
  possible due process claims of the Petitioner.Â  Moreover, the impropriety of
  the solicitorâ€™s closing remarks did not rise to the level which would have
  deprived Petitioner of a fair trial.Â  Therefore, while Petitioner has shown
  error, there is evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s ruling that Petitioner was
  not entitled to relief on this ground.
Based on the
  foregoing reasons, the order of PCR judge denying Petitioner relief is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  The State avers Petitionerâ€™s argument is
  procedurally barred on the ground that it should have been raised in a direct
  appeal.Â  Petitioner, however, did not become aware of his prior relationship
  with Juror Walling until after his direct appeal had been ruled on and he was
  in the process of preparing his petition for post-conviction relief.Â 
  Accordingly, Petitionerâ€™s claim for relief is appropriately based on
  â€œafter-discovered evidence.â€Â  Clark v. State, 315 S.C. 385,
  387-88, 434 S.E.2d 266, 267 (1993).
[2]Â Â  Rule 22 of the South Carolina Rules
  of Criminal Procedure provides, â€œIn arguing before a jury, no attorney shall
  address or refer to by name or otherwise any member of the jury he is
  addressing, or otherwise make any personal appeal to any or all members of the
  jury.â€ Rule 22, SCRCrimP.
