title: State v. Johnson
description: The Court vacates the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 184, 610 S.E.2d 305 (Ct. App. 2005), finding that the State had no right to appeal due to the absence of an error of law in the trial judgeâ€™s decision to grant a new trial.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Petitioner,
				v.
				Rorey Jamar
      Johnson, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI
TO THE SOUTH CAROLINA COURT OF APPEALS
Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26406
Heard November 14, 2007 - Filed December
  17, 2007Â Â  
VACATED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
  and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, all of Columbia, and
  Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Petitioner.
				Chief
  Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Commission on
  Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES: Â Â Â Â Â  The State appealed a
  trial court order granting a new trial based upon testimony regarding a
  polygraph test.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed. State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 184, 610 S.E.2d 305 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  We
  granted the Stateâ€™s petition for certiorari and now vacate the Court of
  Appealsâ€™ decision.
FACTS
Rorey Jamar Johnson
  (Johnson) was charged with the murder of Gregory W. Whitaker (Whitaker).Â 
  Crystal Marion, Alton Henderson, and Michael Jones, Jr. were allegedly with Johnson
  when the murder occurred, and all three testified at trial for the State.Â 
 
Crystal
  Marion was the first witness to testify at trial.Â  When asked whether the third
  and final statement she gave to the police was the whole truth, Marion answered: 
 

	Well,
  the second statement was the truth as well, but, therefore, they kind of made
  me feel like I was lying because I didnâ€™t pass the polygraph test.Â  And the
  second one...Â  

At
  that point, defense counsel moved for a mistrial, which the trial judge denied.Â 
  The judge instructed the jury to disregard the reference to the polygraph. 
 
The
  jury found Johnson guilty of murder.Â  The trial court granted Johnsonâ€™s motion
  for a new trial based upon Marionâ€™s reference to the polygraph.Â  The State
  appealed, and the Court of Appeals affirmed.  
ISSUES

	I.  Does the State have a right to
  appeal an order granting a new trial
  when no error of law exists?
	II.  If the State has a right to
  appeal, did the Court of Appeals err in
  affirming the trial courtâ€™s order granting a new trial based upon testimony
  concerning polygraph test results?

ANALYSIS  
Johnson contends that the State had no right to appeal in this
  case.Â  We agree.
The State may only appeal a new trial order if, in granting it, the
  trial judge committed an error of law. State v. DesChamps, 126 S.C. 416,
  120 S.E. 491 (1923).Â  An error of law exists where a trial judge directed a
  verdict of acquittal after a jury verdict of guilty when there was evidence to
  support the jury verdict. State v. Dasher, 278 S.C. 395, 297 S.E.2d 414
  (1982).Â  When determining whether an error of law exists, and therefore whether
  the State has a right to an appeal, it is necessary to consider the merits of
  the case.Â   
A trial judge has the discretion to grant or deny a motion for a
  new trial, and his decision will not be reversed absent a clear abuse of
  discretion. State v. Simmons, 279 S.C. 165, 166, 303 S.E.2d 857, 858
  (1983).Â  The general rule is that no
  mention of a polygraph test should be placed before the jury.Â  It is thus
  incumbent upon the trial judge to ensure that should such a reference be made,
  no improper inference be drawn therefrom. Â State v. McGuire, 272 S.C.
  547, 551, 253 S.E.2d 103, 105 (1979).Â   
The trial judge found that Marionâ€™s statement about a polygraph
  test prejudiced Johnson.Â  Because the case against Johnson essentially
  consisted of witness testimony, the credibility of each witness was crucial to
  the verdict.Â  Marionâ€™s statement created an inference that bolstered the
  credibility of the Stateâ€™s witnesses.Â  The jury could have believed that the
  State made each witness pass a polygraph test before they were able to testify
  at trial as part of their individual plea bargains. The trial judge did not
  abuse his discretion by granting a new trial.
We find that there is no error of law because the trial judge did
  not abuse his discretion. Â Absent an error of law, the State had no right to
  appeal the new trial order. See State v. DesChamps, supra. 
 

CONCLUSION
We vacate the Court
  of Appealsâ€™ opinion and dismiss the Stateâ€™s appeal.Â  The Court of Appealsâ€™
  opinion is
VACATED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  MOORE, WALLER, JJ., and Acting Justice Dorothy Mobley Jones, concur.Â Â

title: Coakley v. Horace Mann Insurance Co.
description: The Court reversed the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in Coakley v. Horace Mann Ins. Co., 363 S.C. 147, 609 S.E.2d 537 (Ct. App. 2005).  The Court held that excess insurance coverage was not available to Coakley, the injured passenger, because it was predicated on a finding that the owner of the car was not a dependent of the named insured.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				J. Samuel
      Coakley, individually and as Trustee of a Special Needs Trust for Christian
      Coakley, Respondent,
				v.
				Horace Mann
      Insurance Co., Scott Andrew Mitchell, Christopher N. Mitchell and Claudia Dee
      Dee Mitchell, Petitioners.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26407
Heard October 31, 2007 - Filed December
  17, 2007Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Phillip E. Reeves and Jennifer D. Eubanks, both of Gallivan, White
  & Boyd, PA, of Greenville, for Petitioners.
				Benjamin C. Harrison, Max Thomas Hyde, Jr., and 
				
				Jeremy A. Dantin, all of Harrison, White, Smith & Coggins, PC,
  of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Respondent Samuel Coakley, individually and as trustee
  of a special needs trust for his son Christian Coakley (Coakley), sought a
  declaratory judgment to determine the existence and amount of excess automobile
  liability coverage.Â  The circuit court found excess automobile liability
  coverage existed and awarded Coakley $350,000 in excess insurance benefits from
  the named insuredâ€™s policies.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed.Â  Coakley v.
    Horace Mann Ins. Co., 363 S.C. 147, 609 S.E.2d 537 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  We
  granted Horace Mannâ€™s and the Mitchellâ€™s petition for certiorari and now reverse.
FACTS
On
  August 19, 1994, Coakley was a passenger in a car being driven by Scott
  Mitchell (Scott).Â  Scott drove the vehicle off the road and collided with a
  tree.Â  As a result of the one-car accident, Coakley is a permanent
  quadriplegic.
The automobile
  driven by Scott in the accident, a 1984 Mazda RX-7, was owned by Scottâ€™s older
  brother, Christopher Mitchell (Christopher).Â  At the time of the accident,
  Christopher was a student at Clemson University, lived in an apartment in
  Clemson during the school year, and was the primary user of the Mazda RX-7.Â 
  Scott was a high school student and lived with his and Christopherâ€™s mother,
  Claudia â€œDee Deeâ€ Mitchell (Dee Dee).Â  At the time of the accident, Christopher
  was away on a trip and left the car at his motherâ€™s house, and Scott had
  permission to use the car.
Horace Mann insured
  Christopherâ€™s Mazda RX-7, and Dee Dee was the named insured.[1]Â 
  Horace Mann tendered the full liability limit of $50,000 to Coakley from this
  policy.Â  In addition, Dee Dee maintained policies on three other vehicles; two
  of these policies carried liability limits of $50,000, and another policy had a
  liability limit of $250,000.Â  All policies purchased by Dee Dee extended
  liability protection for the operation of non-owned cars.
As part of the
  settlement of the policy limits for the Mazda RX-7, the trust and Horace Mann
  entered into a covenant not to execute.Â  Pursuant to the covenant, Horace Mann
  tendered the $50,000 limit from the policy covering the Mazda RX-7 and allowed
  the trust to bring a declaratory judgment action to determine the applicability
  of Dee Deeâ€™s three additional policies.Â  In exchange, the trust agreed that its
  recovery, if any, would be limited to $350,000, which was the combined total of
  the three policies.
The trust then instituted
  this declaratory judgment action alleging that the three additional policies
  provided excess automobile liability coverage for the Mazda RX-7.Â  The trust
  claimed that the Mazda RX-7 was a non-owned vehicle because Christopher owned
  the car and was not a relative as defined in the policies.
The parties agreed
  to transfer the case to a non-jury docket and then agreed to submit the case to
  a circuit court judge with memoranda of authority, copies of the policies in
  dispute, and the deposition testimony of Dee Dee, Christopher, and Scott
  Mitchell.Â  The circuit court then issued an order finding excess liability
  coverage was available to Coakley under all three policies, resulting in the
  recovery of $350,000.
ISSUES

	I.  Did
  the Court of Appeals err in holding that Christopher Mitchell was not a
  dependent of Dee Dee Mitchell, thereby triggering excess liability coverage?
	II.  If excess
  liability coverage is applicable, did the Court of Â  Appeals err in failing to
  apply policy provisions that purport to limit the  amount of excess coverage
  available to Coakley?

ANALYSIS
Horace Mann argues
  that the Mazda RX-7 owned by Christopher does not qualify as a non-owned
  vehicle under Dee Deeâ€™s policies, thus excess liability coverage is not
  available for Coakley.[2]Â 
  We agree.
A declaratory
  judgment action is neither legal nor equitable, and it is determined by the
  nature of the underlying issue. Â Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354,
  356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991). Â An insurance policy is a contract between the
  insured and the insurance company, and the terms of the policy are to be
  construed according to contract law. Â Est. of Revis v. Revis, 326 S.C.
  470, 476, 484 S.E.2d 112, 115 (Ct. App. 1997). Â In an action at law, on appeal
  of a case tried without a jury, we may not disturb the trial judgeâ€™s findings
  of fact unless those findings are â€œwholly unsupported by the evidence or unless
  it clearly appears the findings are controlled by an error of law.â€Â  Cohenâ€™s
    Drywall Co. v. Sea Spray Homes, LLC, 374 S.C. 195, 198, 648 S.E.2d 598,
  600-601 (2007).Â Â   
Under
  each policy, Scott has excess liability insurance coverage for non-owned cars.Â 
  The provision in each policy reads:
COVERAGE FOR USE OF OTHER CARS

	Bodily
  injury and property damage liability coverages extend to the use, by an
  insured, ofâ€¦ a non-owned car while being used with the permission of the
  driver.[3]

A non-owned
  car is defined in the policies as a private passenger car or utility vehicle
  not: (1) owned by; (2) registered in the name of; or (3) furnished or available
  for the regular or frequent use of the insured or the insuredâ€™s relatives.Â Â Â 
  Dee Dee, the named insured, did not have the title or registration to the Mazda
  RX-7 in her name, nor was the Mazda RX-7 available for her regular or frequent
  use.Â  Horace Mann claims that Christopher is one of Dee Deeâ€™s relatives, which
  would preclude the Mazda RX-7 from qualifying as a non-owned vehicle.Â   
A
  relative is defined in the Horace Mann policies as â€œa person related to you by
  blood, marriage or adoption who lives with you.Â  It includes your unmarried and
  dependent child who is away at school.â€Â  At the time of the accident,
  Christopher was not married and did not live with his mother while he was away
  at Clemson.Â  The issue becomes whether Christopher was a dependent of Dee Dee.Â  
 
The
  circuit court determined that Christopher was not dependent on his mother and
  the Court of Appeals affirmed.Â  Although Christopher stated he did not receive
  money from his mother[4] and that his father would give him a lump sum of money per semester for
  tuition, books, rent, and living expenses, this type of financial assistance to
  a college student is not the sine qua non of dependency.Â  In other words,
  the issue of Christopherâ€™s dependency is not solely a question of who paid the
  majority of his school expenses.
The
  fact that Christopherâ€™s father may have provided the bulk of Christopherâ€™s
  financial support at Clemson does not mean that Christopher was not also
  dependent upon his mother.Â  Dee Dee claimed Christopher as a dependent on her
  income tax returns, albeit pursuant to a court order, and she and Christopherâ€™s
  father shared costs for Christopherâ€™s medical expenses.Â  In addition, Dee Dee
  paid for Christopherâ€™s car taxes and insurance.Â  Other evidence of
  Christopherâ€™s dependency includes Dee Deeâ€™s co-signing on the lease for
  Christopherâ€™s apartment at Clemson and the fact that Dee Dee maintained a bedroom
  at her house[5] to which Christopher often returned on weekends.Â  
 
Accordingly,
  the crucial factual finding that Christopher was not a dependent of Dee Dee is
  wholly unsupported by the evidence.Â  As a result, Christopher is a relative of
  Dee Dee under the Horace Mann policy, the Mazda RX-7 does not constitute a
  non-owned vehicle, and excess liability coverage is not available to Coakley.
CONCLUSION
We
  reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ holding that Coakley was entitled to excess liability
  coverage because it was predicated on the finding that Christopher Mitchell was
  not a dependent of Dee Dee Mitchell.Â  In light of our holding, it is not
  necessary to determine whether the Horace Mann policy limited the amount of
  excess coverage available to Coakley.Â  Futch v. McAllister Towing of
    Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (appellate
  court need not address remaining issue when determination of prior issue is
  dispositive).Â  The Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion is
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Edward B. Cottingham,
  concur.

[1] Scott, as a resident relative of Dee Dee, was an
  insured under all four policies issued to Dee Dee.
[2] Horace Mann acknowledges that if the Mazda RX-7 is a
  non-owned car as defined in the policies, then Scott, the at-fault driver,
  would have excess liability coverage under each of the three remaining policies
  issued to Dee Dee.Â   
[3] A separate policy provision states, â€œIf aâ€¦non-owned
  carâ€¦has other vehicle liability coverage on it, then this coverage is excess.â€
[4] However, Dee Dee testified in her deposition
  that she gave Christopher spending money, grocery money, gas money, and paid for
  Christopherâ€™s auto repairs.
[5] Dee Deeâ€™s address also was the address Christopher
  used on his driverâ€™s license and for his voter registration.Â

title: State v. Stone
description: This is an appeal from a capital sentencing proceeding.  The jury sentenced Appellant Bobby Wayne Stone to death, and Appellant argued on appeal that testimony from the victimâ€™s widow impermissibly injected an arbitrary factor into the juryâ€™s deliberations.  The Court held that the issue was not preserved for review because Appellant did not raise this issue at trial.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Bobby Wayne
      Stone, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Sumter County
Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26408
Heard November 14, 2007 - Filed December
  20, 2007Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Chief
  Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Commission on
  Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General S.
  Creighton Waters, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Cecil Kelly Jackson, of Sumter,
  for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This is an appeal
  from a capital sentencing proceeding.Â  The jury sentenced Appellant Bobby Wayne
  Stone to death, and Appellant argues that testimony from the victimâ€™s widow
  impermissibly injected an arbitrary factor into the juryâ€™s deliberations.Â  Appellant
  did not raise this issue at trial, and the issue is therefore not preserved for
  review.Â Â  For this reason, we express no opinion on the merits, and we affirm
  the trial courtâ€™s decision.Â   

Factual/Procedural Background
This case arises out of the
  shooting death of a Sumter County Sheriffâ€™s Deputy.Â  According to Appellant, he
  began the day leading up to the fatal encounter by purchasing some alcohol and
  two firearms.Â  Appellant spent the remainder of the day wandering in the woods
  near what would become the crime scene, shooting the firearms and becoming
  increasingly intoxicated.Â  Towards the end of the day, Appellant attempted to
  visit the home of an acquaintance near the woods.Â   
The acquaintance asked
  Appellant to leave her property, and the acquaintance later reported the
  incident to the police.Â  After hearing banging on a door to her home and
  gunshots outside her house, the acquaintance phoned the police again.Â  The
  victim was the first officer to respond to the call, and the evidence at trial
  established that Appellant was on the acquaintanceâ€™s porch near a side door
  when the victim arrived at the scene.Â  The occupants of the home directed the
  victim towards the porch as the source of the disturbances, and as the victim
  neared the side porch, he sustained two fatal gunshot wounds.Â  While the State
  alleged that Appellant shot the victim intentionally, Appellant claimed that he
  was startled when the victim turned a corner outside the home and yelled
  â€œHalt!â€ or â€œHold it!â€ and that the gun fired accidentally.
A jury convicted Appellant of
  murder and sentenced him to death.Â  On appeal, this Court affirmed Appellantâ€™s
  convictions but reversed his death sentence.Â  State v. Stone, 350 S.C.
  442, 567 S.E.2d 544 (2002) (remanding for a new sentencing proceeding based on
  the improper exclusion of a juror from the penalty phase, the failure to charge
  the statutory mitigator addressing the defendantâ€™s impairment or mentality at
  the time of the crime, and the failure to instruct the jury that a life sentence
  meant life imprisonment without the possibility of parole).Â  This Court
  remanded the case to the trial court to conduct a second sentencing
  proceeding.Â  Id.Â   
On remand, the State called
  several members of the victimâ€™s family and former co-workers as witnesses.Â  The
  record reveals that the primary purpose of these witnessesâ€™ testimonies was to
  describe the impact of the victimâ€™s death on these individuals and on the
  community.Â  One such witness was the victimâ€™s widow, and in response to a
  question regarding â€œsignificant events in her lifeâ€ since the murder, the
  victimâ€™s widow testified that she had attempted suicide after learning that
  this Court had reversed Appellantâ€™s initial death sentence and that there would
  be another sentencing proceeding in this case.Â  At the conclusion of the second
  sentencing proceeding, the jury sentenced Appellant to death.
This appeal followed, and
  Appellant raises the following issue for review:

	Did the victimâ€™s widowâ€™s testimony
  regarding her suicide attempt impermissibly inject an arbitrary factor into the
  juryâ€™s deliberations?Â  

Law/Analysis
Appellant argues that the
  victimâ€™s widowâ€™s testimony regarding her suicide attempt impermissibly injected
  an arbitrary factor into the juryâ€™s deliberations.Â  We disagree.
Appellantâ€™s argument is not
  preserved for review.Â  At trial, Appellant objected as the victimâ€™s widow began
  to describe her suicide attempt.Â  The record reveals that Appellant based his
  objection on causation grounds, arguing that the testimony implied that the
  cause of the suicide attempt was not the victimâ€™s murder, but the financial
  pressures the victimâ€™s widow was experiencing and the fact that Appellant would
  have another sentencing proceeding.Â  In allowing the testimony, the trial court
  held that the victimâ€™s widow had attributed the facts relayed in the testimony
  to her relationship with the victim, and that the testimony was therefore
  relevant and admissible.
Appellantâ€™s argument before
  this Court goes along quite different lines.Â  Appellant now argues that the
  victimâ€™s widowâ€™s testimony improperly invited the jury to speculate about the
  finality of its decision on the appropriate punishment and improperly invited
  the jury to consider how its decision might impact the victimâ€™s widowâ€™s future
  health.Â  Thus, while Appellantâ€™s argument below focused on what caused the
  victimâ€™s widow to attempt suicide - meaning, what caused the testimony to be
  relevant - Appellantâ€™s argument on appeal abandons the issue of relevance and addresses
  only the effect this testimony may have had on the jury.Â  Because Appellant did
  not argue these grounds in support of his objection at trial, Appellantâ€™s
  argument is not preserved for review.Â  See State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C.
  138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 693 (2003) (providing that in order for an issue
  to be preserved for appellate review, it must have been raised to and ruled
  upon by the trial court).
Appellant alleges that his
  argument on appeal is simply an augmentation of his objection at trial, but a thoughtful
  examination reveals that this is not so.Â  Primarily, Appellantâ€™s objection at
  trial was based on relevance, and that issue has been abandoned here.Â  Second,
  whether the suicide attempt by the victimâ€™s spouse minimized the juryâ€™s sense
  of responsibility (by suggesting that the juryâ€™s ultimate decision would be
  subject to review by a higher court) or maximized the juryâ€™s sense of
  responsibility (by implying that imposing a life sentence might lead the
  victimâ€™s widow to attempt suicide again), these considerations are wholly independent
  of the relevance argument presented below.Â  If a pitch was never thrown at
  trial, we cannot review whether the trial court made the proper call.[1]
For these reasons, we hold
  that Appellantâ€™s argument is not preserved for review.

Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we
  affirm Appellantâ€™s sentence.Â  Our review of similar prior cases illustrates
  that imposing the death sentence in this case would be neither excessive nor
  disproportionate in light of the crime and the defendant.Â  See State v. Sapp, 366
  S.C. 283, 621 S.E.2d 883 (2005) (holding that
  the death penalty was warranted where defendant killed a law enforcement
  officer while the officer was performing his official duties); State v.
    Hughes, 336 S.C. 585, 521 S.E.2d 500 (1999) (same); and State v.
      Johnson, 306 S.C. 119, 410 S.E.2d 547 (1991) (same).
MOORE, WALLER,
  PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] It is important to note that in State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406
  S.E.2d 315 (1991), we held that South Carolinaâ€™s strict error preservation
  rules are no less applicable in death penalty cases.Â

description: This is a workers' compensation case involving a claim by an illegal alien worker.
text:
Curiel v. Environmental


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Mario B. Curiel, Respondent,
				v.
				Environmental Management
      Services (MS), Employer, Reliance National Insurance Company, and S.C.
      Property & Casualty Insurance Guaranty Association, Carrier, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal from Charleston County
Perry M. Buckner, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26409
Heard October 30, 2007 - Filed December 20, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


	
		
			
				J. Hubert Wood, III, and Jason A. Williams, both of Wood,
  Porter & Warder, L.L.C., of Charleston, for appellants Environmental
  Management Services and Reliance National Insurance.
				Darryl D. Smalls, of
  Nelson, Mullins, Riley & Scarborough, L.L.P., of Columbia, for appellant
  S.C. Property and Casualty Insurance Guaranty Association.
				J. Kevin Holmes, of The
  Steinberg Law Firm, of Charleston, for respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  MOORE:Â  This appeal is from the circuit
  courtâ€™s order regarding temporary total workersâ€™ compensation benefits and a
  permanent impairment rating.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTS
Respondent Curiel (Claimant) filed
  this claim for workersâ€™ compensation benefits after he was struck in the right
  eye on April 12, 2000, while doing demolition work for his employer, appellant
  Environmental Management Services (Employer).Â  Claimant suffered a detached
  retina in his right eye.Â  Employerâ€™s compensation carrier, Reliance National
  Insurance Company, is insolvent, and appellant S.C. Property & Casualty
  Insurance Guaranty Association (Fund) is responsible for benefits.
The single commissioner found Claimant had a
  compensable injury to his right eye and awarded permanent benefits based on a
  60% loss of use.Â  The commissioner denied temporary total benefits.Â  Claimant,
  Employer, and Fund all appealed.Â  The Commissionâ€™s Appellate Panel (hereinafter
  â€œthe Commissionâ€) adopted the findings of the single commissioner but found
  Claimant suffered only a 41.5% loss of use of his right eye rather than 60%.Â 
  Again, all parties appealed.  
The circuit court found Claimant
  should have been awarded temporary total benefits, and the award of permanent
  benefits should have taken into consideration the combined effect of the injury
  to Claimantâ€™s right eye and the pre-existing loss of vision in his left eye.Â 
  The circuit court remanded to the Commission to determine benefits
  accordingly.Â  Employer and Fund appeal.
ISSUES

	
		
			1. 
			Does federal law preempt 
			entitlement under our Workerâ€™s Compensation Act?
 
		
		
			2.
			Is there substantial evidence to 
			support the commissionerâ€™s findings regarding maximum medical 
			improvement and temporary total benefits?
 
		
		
			3. 
			Did the circuit court err in 
			remanding for the Commission to consider a pre-existing impairment 
			to Claimantâ€™s left eye?
 
		
		
			4. 
			Is the Fund liable for this 
			claim?
		
	

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Preemption under federal law
Claimant is a Mexican national and
  is admittedly an illegal alien worker.Â  He used fraudulent documents to
  misrepresent his legal status when applying for the job with Employer in 1997.Â 
  Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-130 (Supp. 2006), for purposes of workersâ€™
  compensation, â€œemployeeâ€ is defined as:

	Every person engaged in an employment .
  . . including aliens and also including minors, whether lawfully or
    unlawfully employed.

(emphasis added).Â  The single commissioner, the Commission,
  and the circuit court all found Claimant was entitled to benefits under the
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.
Employer contends Claimant is not entitled to
  benefits because federal law preempts state law regarding the payment of
  benefits to an illegal alien worker.Â  Employer cites the federal Immigration
  Reform and Control Act of 1986 (IRCA) which prohibits the hiring of
  unauthorized aliens or the tendering of fraudulent documents to obtain
  employment.Â  8 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 1324a & c.Â  Although IRCA contains no specific
  provision forbidding workersâ€™ compensation benefits to illegal alien workers,
  Employer argues that the policy of IRCA prohibiting the hiring of illegal
  aliens conflicts with, and therefore preempts, state law allowing such
  payments.Â   
North Carolina, which has the same statutory
  language as Â§ 42-1-130 regarding alien employees, has addressed this precise
  issue and ruled that IRCA does not preempt an award of workersâ€™ compensation
  benefits under state law.Â  Ruiz v. Belk Masonry Co., 559 S.E.2d 249
  (N.C. App. 2002).Â  We find the analysis in Ruiz persuasive.Â  The Ruiz court noted a Congressional report on IRCA stating â€œ[i]t is not the intention
  of the Committee that the employer sanctions provisions of [IRCA] be used to
  undermine or diminish in any way labor protections in existing law. . . .â€Â  Id. at 678.Â  IRCA does not expressly preclude an illegal alien from being considered
  an employee for workersâ€™ compensation benefits, and Ruiz concluded there
  is no indication preemption was intended.Â  Id.Â  Other state
  courts have ruled the same way.Â  See, e.g., Safeharbor Employer
    Servs. I, Inc. v. Cinto Velazquez, 860 So.2d 984 (Fla. App. 2003); Earth
      First Grading & Builders Ins. Group/Assâ€™n Servs, Inc, v. Gutierrez, 606
  S.E.2d 332 (Ga. App. 2004); Design Kitchen and Baths v. Lagos, 882 A.2d
  817 (Md. 2005); Correa v. Waymouth Farms, Inc., 664 N.W.2d 324 (Minn. 2003).Â  
 
Further, allowing benefits to
  injured illegal alien workers does not conflict with the IRCAâ€™s policy against
  hiring them.Â  To the contrary, disallowing benefits would mean unscrupulous
  employers could hire undocumented workers without the burden of insuring them, a
  consequence that would encourage rather than discourage the hiring of illegal
  workers.
We find IRCA does not preempt state
  law and Claimant is not precluded from benefits under our Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Act.
2.Â  Maximum medical improvement and temporary total
  disability
Employer contends it was error for
  the circuit court to reverse the commissionerâ€™s findings regarding maximum
  medical improvement and temporary total benefits. We agree.
The single commissioner found
  Claimant reached maximum medical improvement on October 3, 2002.Â  This is the
  date of a letter from one of Claimantâ€™s treating physicians, Dr. Farr,
  indicating Claimantâ€™s â€œeye condition is stable at this point.â€Â  Dr. Farr
  treated Claimantâ€™s eye pressure which was unacceptably high following the
  retinal detachment injury.Â  Dr. Farr indicated Claimantâ€™s eye pressure was
  controlled with eye drops; he further noted that Claimant should see a low
  vision specialist to evaluate him for glasses.  
On appeal, the circuit court found
  Claimant could not have reached maximum medical improvement on October 3, 2002,
  in light of Dr. Farrâ€™s recommendation that Claimantâ€™s vision could further
  improve with low vision care.Â  Further, the court found that even if Claimant
  reached maximum medical improvement on October 3, 2002, as found by the
  commissioner, Claimant should have been awarded temporary total benefits from
  the date he was terminated until that date. The circuit court remanded for the
  commissioner to determine the proper award for temporary total benefits.Â  
 
Essentially, workersâ€™ compensation
  benefits accrue along a time continuum:Â  temporary total disability benefits
  are available from the date of injury through the date of maximum medical
  improvement;Â  post-MMI benefits may then be awarded either as a permanent total
  or partial disability, or as a percentage of impairment to a scheduled member.Â  Smith v. NCCI, Inc., 369 S.C. 236, 631 S.E.2d 268 (Ct. App. 2006).Â 
  Accordingly, the date of maximum medical improvement signals the end of
  entitlement to temporary total benefits.Â   
The term â€œmaximum medical
  improvementâ€ means a person has reached such a plateau that, in the physicianâ€™s
  opinion, no further medical care or treatment will lessen the period of
  impairment.Â  Hall v. United Rentals, Inc., 371 S.C. 69, 89, 636 S.E.2d
  876, 887 (Ct. App. 2006); Lee v. Harborside CafÃ©, 350 S.C. 74, 81, 564
  S.E.2d 354, 358 (Ct. App. 2002); Dodge v. Bruccoli, Clark, Layman, Inc.,
  334 S.C. 574, 581, 514 S.E.2d 593, 596 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Maximum medical
  improvement is a factual determination by the Commission.Â  Hall, supra.Â 
  Factual determinations by the Commission must be upheld on review unless
  unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C.
  448, 454, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â   
Here, the commissioner found
  Claimant had reached maximum medical improvement based on Dr. Farrâ€™s assessment
  that his eye condition was stable as of October 3, 2002.Â  The fact that
  Claimantâ€™s sight could have been improved with corrective lenses does not
  impact his impairment rating.Â  Evidence that loss of vision might be reduced by
  the use of corrective lenses is not to be considered in determining impairment
  to vision for purposes of workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  Dykes v. Daniel
    Constr. Co., 262 S.C. 98, 106, 202 S.E.2d 646, 650 (1974); see also S.C.
  Reg. 67-1105A (â€œLoss of vision is based on reading without corrective lenses.â€).Â 
  The commissionerâ€™s finding regarding the date of maximum medical improvement is
  therefore supported by the record and the circuit court erred in reversing this
  finding.
Further, the circuit court held in
  the alternative that if Claimant did reach maximum medical improvement on
  October 3, 2002, he should have received temporary total benefits from the date
  of his termination until that date. Â Â 
Claimant was terminated from his
  job on January 21, 2002, more than two years after his accident.Â  He testified
  he was fired when Employer learned Claimantâ€™s vision was worse than it seemed.Â 
  Claimant stated that he pretended to see better than he actually could in order
  to keep his job.Â  Employerâ€™s president testified:

	
		
			A. 
			[Claimant] was told until he got 
			his vision corrected he couldnâ€™t work.  He came in the office 
			one day and acted like he was drunk, and I, you know, asked him, and 
			he said he couldnâ€™t see. . . .
 
		
		
			Q. 
			So he was, I guess - are we 
			saying was he terminated, or is it that if his vision is corrected, 
			heâ€™s got a job?
 
		
		
			A. 
			Yeah, I wouldnâ€™t have any 
			problem hiring him back if     his vision is 
			corrected.
		
	

Claimantâ€™s termination form indicates he would be considered
  for rehiring but â€œneed[s] to have his eyes fixed before rehire.â€Â   
The commissioner concluded Claimant
  was not entitled to temporary total benefits because Claimant had exaggerated
  the degree of his vision loss.Â  The commissioner found:

	Had the Claimant been honest with his
  physicians concerning the sight in his right eye, a corrective lens could have
  been provided, and the Claimant could have worked.Â  

The record supports the
  commissionerâ€™s finding that Claimantâ€™s failure to cooperate with his physicians
  resulted in his uncorrected vision and resulting inability to work.Â  Dr. Farr
  testified he suspected Claimant was exaggerating his vision loss and that it
  was difficult to assess Claimantâ€™s actual vision.Â  Claimantâ€™s vision in his
  right eye was evaluated by Dr. Morse at 20/80 after the date of maximum medical
  improvement.Â  Tests performed by Dr. Morse indicated that Claimantâ€™s earlier
  assessment at 20/300 to 20/400 was inaccurate and that Claimant was not fully
  cooperating in the vision testing.Â  Dr. Farr explained that a patientâ€™s vision
  cannot be corrected without accurate feedback from the patient.Â  This evidence
  supports the commissionerâ€™s conclusion that Claimantâ€™s failure to cooperate was
  the cause of his uncorrected vision.
In conclusion, the commissionerâ€™s
  findings regarding maximum medical improvement and temporary total disability
  are supported by the record and should not have been reversed by the circuit
  court.
3.Â 
  Pre-existing loss of vision in left eye
The commissioner concluded Claimant
  had suffered an impairment of 60% to his right eye.Â  The Commission reduced
  this award to 41.5% which is the impairment rating for an uncorrected vision of
  20/80, the assessment given by Dr. Morse.Â  See S.C. Reg. 67-1105C.Â  The
  circuit court found the Commission should have considered the impaired vision
  in Claimantâ€™s left eye in determining an impairment rating.Â  Employer contends
  this was error.
Claimant testified that before the injury to his
  right eye on April 12, 2000, he had a work-related injury to his left eye and
  he can see only light and dark from that eye.Â  All of the medical evidence corroborates
  that Claimant has little or no vision in his left eye and there is physical
  evidence of an old injury to that eye.Â   
Under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, an injured
  claimant is entitled to compensation and medical benefits for disability arising
  from a permanent physical impairment in combination with a pre-existing
  impairment if the combined effect results in a substantially greater
  disability.Â  Ellison v. Frigidaire Home Prods., 371 S.C. 159, 638 S.E.2d
  664 (2006) (applying S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-400 (1985 & Supp. 2005)).Â  The
  Commission erred as a matter of law in failing to consider Claimantâ€™s
  pre-existing impairment in his left eye in combination with the injury to his
  right eye in determining his impairment rating.Â  The circuit court properly
  reversed and remanded on this issue.
5.Â 
  Claimantâ€™s residency
In addition to the issues raised by Employer, the
  Fund contends it is not liable for Claimantâ€™s claim because Claimant is not a South Carolina resident.Â  Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-31-20(8) (Supp. 2006), the Fund is
  obligated to cover a claim if â€œthe claimant or insured is a resident of this
  State at the time of the insured event. . . .â€Â   
The Fund contends Claimant does not
  qualify as a resident because his address on file with Employer is a Salisbury, North Carolina address, and in any event he is not a legal resident given his
  status as an illegal alien.Â  Claimant testified he moved to Charleston in 1997
  when he began working for Employer and has physically resided there since that
  time.Â  There is nothing in the record indicating Claimant was actually living
  in Salisbury at the time of his accident.Â   
Moreover, Â§ 38-31-20(8) provides a
  claim is covered by the Fund if the claimant or the insured is a South Carolina resident.[1]Â 
  There is no allegation that Employer, who is the insured party, does not
  qualify as a resident.
CONCLUSION
We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s order
  remanding to the Commission to determine disability based on the combined
  effect of Claimantâ€™s vision impairment in both eyes and reverse the circuit
  courtâ€™s order remanding for an award of temporary total benefits.Â  Employerâ€™s
  remaining issue is without merit and we dispose of it pursuant to Rule 220(b),
  SCACR.Â  See Cooper v. McDevitt & Street Co., 260 S.C. 463,
  196 S.E.2d 833 (1973) (false representation regarding an employeeâ€™s physical condition).Â  
 
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN
  PART.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER,
  PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur. 

[1] If the insured in not an individual, residence is
  determined by the location ofÂ  the principal place of business.

title: Coggeshall v. Reproductive Endocrine Associates
description: This case involves general and specific jurisdiction over a non-resident defendant.
text:
Coggeshall v. Repro


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Chandler Coggeshall and Susan
      Coggeshall, individually, and as Guardians for their Minor Child Lawton
      Coggeshall,
				Of whom 
				Chandler Coggeshall and Susan
        Coggeshall are, Appellants,
				v.
				Reproductive Endocrine
      Associates of Charlotte, Jack L. Crain, M.D., and Edward E. Moore, M.D.,
      d/b/a Carolina Center for Fertility and Endocrinology, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal from Richland County
G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26410
Heard September 19, 2007 - Filed December 20, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED  


	
		
			Thomas A. Pendarvis, of Pendarvis Law Offices, P.C., of
  Beaufort; and A. Camden Lewis and Ariail E. King, both of Lewis & Babcock,
  L.L.P., of Columbia, for appellants.
			Samuel W. Outten, of
  Womble, Carlyle, Sandridge & Ride, of Greenville, Sara R. Lincoln, of
  Womble Carlyle Sandridge & Rice, of Charlotte, North Carolina; and Julius
  W. McKay, II, of McKay, Cauthen, Settana & Stubley, P.A., of Columbia, for
  respondent.
		
	


JUSTICE
  MOORE: Â Appellants
  (â€œthe Coggeshallsâ€), residents of Richland County, commenced this action for damages
  resulting from medical care provided by respondent (REACH), a fertility clinic
  located in Charlotte, North Carolina. Â The trial judge dismissed the complaint
  for lack of personal jurisdiction under Rule 12(b)(2), SCRCP.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
As alleged in their complaint, in November 2000
  the Coggeshalls consulted respondent Dr. Crain at REACH regarding in vitro
  fertilization (IVF).Â  In preparation for IVF, Dr. Crain referred Susan
  Coggeshall to respondent Dr. Moore in Columbia for pre-implantation testing and
  monitoring.Â  The Coggeshalls subsequently signed a contract with REACH for IVF
  services.Â  After embryo implantation, Susan became pregnant.Â  At fourteen weeks
  gestation, amniocentesis revealed a chromosomal abnormality identified as Down
  Syndrome.Â  In a subsequent telephone conversation, Dr. Crain advised the
  Coggeshalls to have pre-implantation genetic testing if they wanted to use IVF
  in the future.Â  This was the first time the Coggeshall were made aware that
  such testing was available.
The Coggeshallsâ€™ child was born with Down
  Syndrome.Â  The Coggeshalls then brought this action against REACH, Dr. Crain,
  and Dr. Moore for failure to inform them of pre-implantation genetic testing.Â 
  Their complaint alleges they will suffer â€œsubstantial financial expensesâ€ in
  caring for a child with Down Syndrome.
In lieu of answering the complaint, the North Carolina defendants, REACH and Dr. Crain, moved to dismiss for lack of personal
  jurisdiction; Dr. Moore moved to dismiss for failure to state a claim under South Carolina law.Â  The trial judge granted both motions.Â  The Coggeshalls appeal the
  dismissal of their complaint against REACH and Dr. Crain.
ISSUES

	1.     Is there
  â€œgeneral jurisdictionâ€ under Â§ 36-2-802?
	2.     Is there
  â€œspecific jurisdictionâ€ under Â§ 36-2-803?

DISCUSSION
A.Â 
  Background and procedure 
Personal jurisdiction is exercised as â€œgeneral
  jurisdictionâ€ or â€œspecific jurisdiction.â€Â  General jurisdiction is the Stateâ€™s
  right to exercise personal jurisdiction over a defendant even though the suit
  does not arise out of or relate to the defendantâ€™s contacts with the forum, Burger
    King Corp. v. Rudzewicz, 471 U.S. 462, 473 n.15 (1985); general
  jurisdiction is determined under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-802 (2003).Â  Specific
  jurisdiction is the Stateâ€™s right to exercise personal jurisdiction because the
  cause of action arises specifically from a defendantâ€™s contacts with the forum;
  specific jurisdiction is determined under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-803 (2003).Â  Cockrell
    v. Hillerich & Bradsby Co., 363 S.C. 485, 611 S.E.2d 505 (2005). Â The
  exercise of personal jurisdiction under either statute must comport with due
  process requirements and must not offend traditional notions of fair play and
  substantial justice.Â  Id.Â  Due process requires some act by which
  the defendant purposefully avails itself of the privilege of conducting
  activities within the forum state.Â  Hanson v. Denckla, 357 U.S. 235 (1958).Â  
 
At the pretrial stage,
  the burden of proving personal jurisdiction over a nonresident is met by a
  prima facie showing of jurisdiction.Â  Id.Â  When a motion to dismiss
  attacks the allegations of the complaint on the issue of jurisdiction, the court
  is not confined to the allegations of the complaint but may resort to
  affidavits or other evidence to determine jurisdiction.Â  Graham v. Lloydâ€™s
    of London, 296 S.C. 249, 251 n. 1, 371 S.E.2d 801, 802 n. 1 (Ct. App. 1988).Â 
  The decision of the trial court will be affirmed unless unsupported by the
  evidence or influenced by an error of law.Â  Cockrell, supra. 
 
B.Â  General jurisdiction under Â§ 36-2-802

	The trial judge ruled that jurisdiction was not
  proper under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-802 (2003) which provides in pertinent part:
	Â§ 36-2-802.Â  Personal
  jurisdiction based upon enduring relationship 
	A court may exercise personal
  jurisdiction over a person . . . doing business . . . [in] this
  State as to any cause of action.

The Coggeshalls contend REACHâ€™s activities
  in South Carolina constitute â€œdoing businessâ€ in the state and therefore
  jurisdiction is proper.Â  They point to REACHâ€™s answers to interrogatories which
  indicate the following:

	- REACH performed services for nearly
  three thousand South Carolina residents between 2000 and 2004 and sent bills to
  South Carolina; 
	- REACH earned over $2 million from South Carolina patients during that period which represents less than 1% of REACHâ€™s income;
	
	- REACH received referrals from at
  least twelve South Carolina healthcare providers; 
	- REACH is a member of the IntegraMed
  Network of Infertility which has one member in South Carolina; 
	- REACH has referred South Carolina
  patients to two other medical practices in South Carolina, in addition to Dr.
  Moore, for the patientsâ€™ convenience; 
	- Of 55 the vendors with whom REACH
  does business, five are located in South Carolina. 

There is no universal formula for determining what
  constitutes â€œdoing businessâ€ to subject a foreign entity to personal
  jurisdiction; the question must be resolved on the facts of each case.Â  Troy
    H. Cribb & Sons, Inc. v. Cliffstar Corp., 273 S.C. 623, 258 S.E.2d 108
  (1979).Â  As the title of Â§ 36-2-802 indicates, general jurisdiction is based
  upon â€œan enduring relationshipâ€ with the State.Â  An enduring relationship is
  indicated by contacts that are substantial, continuous, and systematic.Â  Cockrell,
  363 S.C. at 495, 611 S.E.2d at 510 (citing Helicopteros Nacionales de
    Colombia, S.A. v. Hall, 466 U.S. 408 (1984); Internatâ€™l Shoe Co. v. Washington,
  326 U.S. 310 (1945)).Â   
In this instance, REACH and Dr.
  Crain do not have contacts with South Carolina that are substantial,
  continuous, and systematic to justify the exercise of personal jurisdiction.Â  Neither
  Dr. Crain nor any of the REACH physicians is licensed to practice medicine in South Carolina; all of the medical care they rendered was rendered in North Carolina.Â 
  Medical services differ from other types of commercial activity because of the
  very personal nature of the service rendered.Â  Hume v. Durwood Med. Clinic,
    Inc., 282 S.C. 236, 318 S.E.2d 119 (Ct. App. 1984), cert. dismissed, 285
  S.C. 377, 329 S.E.2d 443 (1985), cert. denied, 474 U.S. 848 (1985); accord Wolf v. Richmond County Hosp. Auth., 745 F.2d 904 (4th Cir.
  1984).Â  As several courts have noted:

	When one seeks out services which are
  personal in nature, such as those rendered by attorneys, physicians, dentists,
  hospitals or accountants, and travels to the locality where he knows the
  services will actually be rendered, he must realize that the services are not
  directed to impact on any particular place, but are directed to the needy
  person himself. . . . [I]t would be fundamentally unfair to permit a suit in
  whatever distant jurisdiction the patient may carry the consequences of his
  treatment. . . . 

Gelineau v. New York Univ. Hosp., 375 F. Supp. 661,
  667 (D.N.J. 1974).Â   
Because medical care is of such a
  personal nature, jurisdiction over an out-of-state physician is generally not
  exercised absent other circumstances indicating a purposeful availment of the
  forum stateâ€™s market.Â  See Wright v. Yackley, 459 F.2d 287 (9th Cir. 1972); Soares v. Roberts, 417 F. Supp. 304 (D.R.I. 1976); Woodward
    v. Keenan, 261 N.W.2d 80 (Mich. App. 1977); S.R. v. City of Fairmont, 280 S.E.2d 712 (W.Va. App. 1981); see generally Annot. 25 A.L.R.4th 706 (1983).Â  Here, we find no such purposeful availment.
Although REACH has served a fair
  number of South Carolina patients, REACH does not target its advertising to South Carolina Â residents nor does it systematically search out patients here.Â  REACH
  maintains a website accessible by South Carolina residents but it is simply an
  informational website that allows prospective patients to email for
  information.Â  This type of â€œpassiveâ€ website does not direct business
  activities to a particular forum.Â  See Holland America Line, Inc. v.
    Wartsila North Amer., Inc., 485 F.3d 450 (9th Cir. 2007); Jennings
      v. AC Hydraulic A/S, 383 F.3d 546 (10th Cir. 2004)
  (distinguishing between interactive and passive websites for purposes of
  personal jurisdiction); see also McBee v. Delica Co., 417 F.3d
  107 (1st Cir. 2005) (noting that given omnipresence of internet
  websites, allowing personal jurisdiction to be premised on such a contact alone
  would eviscerate limits on stateâ€™s jurisdiction).
We decline to hold that REACH or
  Dr. Crain is doing business in South Carolina based on their unsolicited patient
  contacts or tangential business dealings with vendors here.Â  We therefore
  conclude the trial judge properly refused to exercise personal jurisdiction
  under Â§ 36-2-802.[1]
C.Â  Specific jurisdiction under Â§36-2-803
The Coggeshalls contend REACH and
  Dr. Crain are subject to specific personal jurisdiction under S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  36-2-803 (2003) which provides in pertinent part:

	Â§ 36-2-803.Â  Personal jurisdiction based on conduct.
	Â (A) A court may exercise personal
  jurisdiction over a person who acts directly or by an agent as to a cause of
  action arising from the personâ€™s:
	Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (1) transacting any business
  in this State;

. . .  

	
		(4) causing tortious injury
  or death in this State by an act or omission outside this State if he regularly
  does or solicits business, or engages in any other persistent course of
  conduct, or derives substantial revenue from goods used or consumed or services
  rendered in this State;
	

. .
  .

	
		(7) entry into a contract to
  be performed in whole or in part by either party in this State;Â  . . .
	
	(B) When jurisdiction over a person is
  based solely upon this section, only a cause of action arising from acts
  enumerated in this section may be asserted against him.

As noted in subsection (B),
  jurisdiction under this section is limited to a cause of action arising from a
  specific activity within this State.Â  Under subsection (A)(1), â€œtransacting any
  business,â€ the business activities of REACH and Dr. Crain that occurred in South
  Carolina, which included billing patients and doing business with vendors, did
  not give rise to the alleged tort in this case.Â  This subsection does not
  apply.
Regarding subsection (A)(4),
  â€œcausing tortious injury,â€ the tortious injury did not occur in South Carolina but in North Carolina where the medical treatment was rendered.Â  We concur
  with the substantial number of cases finding that the tortious injury occurs in
  the forum where the medical treatment was given and not where the patient
  resides.Â  See Wright v. Yackley, 459 F.2d 287 (9th Cir. 1972) (medical treatment is personal service and tort occurred where
  service rendered for purposes of personal jurisdiction); Lemke v. St.
    Margaret Hosp., 552 F. Supp. 883 (N.D. Ill. 1982); Glover v. Wagner,
  462 F. Supp. 308 (D. Neb. 1978); Gelineau v. New York Univ. Hosp., 375
  F. Supp. 661 (D. N.J. 1974); Simmons v. State, 670 P.2d 1372 (Mont. 1983);Â  Brocail v. Anderson, 132 S.W.3d 552 (Tex. App. 2004).
Finally, regarding
  subsection (A)(7), â€œentry into a contract,â€ the Coggeshallsâ€™ payment on the
  contract in South Carolina is the only part of the contract performed here and
  this alone is not sufficient to justify the exercise of personal jurisdiction
  over REACH and Dr. Crain.Â  Further, the contract in this case provides that North Carolina law applies to any claim arising from the agreement.Â  Although not
  controlling, a choice of law provision is relevant in deciding whether to exercise
  personal jurisdiction.Â  Springmasters, Inc. v. D&M Mfg., 303 S.C.
  528, 402 S.E.2d 192 (Ct. App. 1991) (citing Burger King Corp., supra).Â 
  The choice of North Carolina law in the agreement indicates REACH did not
  intend to avail itself of the benefits and protections of South Carolina law by
  entering a contract with a South Carolina resident.Â  Burger King Corp.,
  471 U.S. at 482 (purposeful availment is touchstone of due process for personal
  jurisdiction).Â   
In conclusion, we
  hold the trial judge did not err in declining to exercise specific personal
  jurisdiction under Â§ 36-2-803.Â   
AFFIRMED.
WALLER, J., and
  Acting Justice E. C. Burnett, III, concur. TOAL, C.J., concurring in result in
  a separate opinion in which BEATTY, J., concurs.

Chief Justice Toal: 
Although I
  concur in the result reached by the majority, I respectfully disagree with the
  analysis and conclusion regarding personal jurisdiction.Â   
The
  determination of whether a court may exercise personal jurisdiction over a
  non-resident defendant involves a two-step analysis.Â  White v. Stephens, 300 S.C. 241, 245,
  387 S.E.2d 260, 262 (1990). Â First, in order for
  the courts to have statutory authority to exercise jurisdiction, the
  nonresident defendantâ€™s conduct must meet the requirements of South Carolinaâ€™s
  long-arm statute.[2]Â  Id. Â In relevant part, South Carolina courts may exercise
  personal jurisdiction over a person who transacts business in this State or who enters into a contract to be performed in whole or
  in part in this State.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-803(1) and (7) (2003).Â  In
  my view, REACH transacted business in the State by contacting Dr. Moore and
  arranging for part of the IVF procedure to be performed in Columbia.Â  Likewise,
  since Dr. Mooreâ€™s services were a necessary part of the IVF procedure, I
  believe REACH consequently entered into a contract with the Coggeshalls which
  was performed in part in this State.Â  For these reasons, I disagree with the
  majorityâ€™s jurisdictional analysis, and I would hold that South Carolina may
  exercise personal jurisdiction over REACH pursuant to our long-arm statute.
The second step
  in the analysis is whether the exercise of personal jurisdiction comports with
  the requirements of due process.Â  Cockrell
    v. Hillerich & Bradsby Co., 363
  S.C. 485, 491-92, 611 S.E.2d 505, 508 (2005).Â 
  In my opinion, exercising personal jurisdiction over REACH in this case would
  not violate due process.Â  REACH purposefully sought out Dr. Moore in Columbia to perform services that were integral to the IVF procedure.Â  Additionally, REACH
  admits it has treated thousands of South Carolinians over the past eight years,
  which is mostly likely a result of its office location in Charlotte, adjacent
  to the South Carolina/North Carolina border.Â  See Cockrell, 363 at 485, 491-92, 611 at 508 (2005)
  (noting that due process requires minimum contacts between the
  defendant and the forum state such that maintenance of the suit does not offend
  traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice and such that the
  defendant could reasonably anticipate being haled into court there).Â  I
  disagree with the majorityâ€™s analysis in distinguishing between defendants that
  render medical services and all other defendants.Â  By asserting this
  distinction, the majority suggests that courts should apply profession-specific
  standards under which to measure due process requirements, thereby effectively
  making a policy decision.Â  In my view, such policy decisions are better left to
  the legislature.
Despite finding personal jurisdiction, however, I would affirm the
  trial courtâ€™s dismissal.Â  In my opinion, the Coggeshalls do not allege an
  injury entitling them to relief.Â  Specifically, the Coggeshalls contend they
  will suffer substantial financial expenses in caring for their child; however,
  the Coggeshalls do not allege that the failure to administer the
  pre-implantation testing caused their childâ€™s condition.Â  David v. McLeod
    Regional Medical Center, 367
  S.C. 242, 248, 626 S.E.2d 1, 4 (2006) (holding that a
  plaintiff in a medical malpractice case must show that the defendantsâ€™
  negligence was the proximate cause of the alleged injuries and damages).Â 
  Therefore, despite their argument to the contrary, the Coggeshalls are
  essentially seeking damages directly resulting from their child being born.Â  I
  see no actual difference between this claim and a claim for wrongful life, a
  claim which we have explicitly rejected.Â  See Willis v. Wu, 362
  S.C. 146, 171, 607 S.E.2d 63, 71 (2004).
For these
  reasons, I would hold that although a South Carolina court may exercise
  personal jurisdiction over REACH, the Coggeshalls failed to present an injury
  to which they are entitled to relief.Â   
BEATTY, J., concurs

[1] The Coggeshalls also contend the trial judge erred in failing to find Dr.
  Moore, a South Carolina physician practicing in Columbia, acted as the agent of
  REACH and Dr. Crain, and therefore personal jurisdiction was appropriate.Â  This
  argument is not preserved for review.Â  The trial judgeâ€™s order regarding REACH
  and Dr. Crain makes no finding regarding any alleged agency relationship
  between Dr. Moore and REACH.Â  Although the Coggeshallsâ€™ brief refers to a
  motion to amend which may have raised this issue, the motion itself is not
  included in the record and the trial judgeâ€™s order on the motion to amend is
  simply a summary denial.Â  There is nothing in the record indicating the issue
  of agency was ever considered or ruled upon by the trial judge.Â  Accordingly,
  it is not preserved for review.Â  Madison ex rel. Bryant v. Babcock Center, 371 S.C. 123, 638 S.E.2d 650 (2006).Â  
 
[2] Additionally, a court may exercise personal
  jurisdiction as to any cause of action over a person based upon an â€œenduring
  relationshipâ€ with the State pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-802 (2003).Â 
  Although, in my view, South Carolina may arguably exercise personal
  jurisdiction under this statute as well, any analysis of this issue is
  unnecessary given that the long-arm statute is applicable.
